headline: One Way To Look At Private Equity

abstract: Caucus column; Jon M Huntsman Jr, after abandoning White House bid and endorsing Mitt Romney, removes video advertisements attacking Romney from his campaign Web site and YouTube channel. (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Campaign Cleanup: Attacks? What Attacks?

abstract: David Carr The Media Equation column observes that documentary-style film When Mitt Romney Came to Town, which relentlessly attacks Mitt Romney, has unnerved some in Hollywood with its similarities to expose-type films by director Michael Moore; points out film was paid for by supporters of Newt Gingrich.
author: DAVID CARR
headline: Hollywood Techniques at Play in Politics

abstract: A documentary-style film relentlessly attacking Mitt Romney has unnerved some in Hollywood with its attention to form.
author: DAVID CARR
headline: Hollywood Techniques At Play In Politics

abstract: Jon M Huntsman Jr informs his advisers he intends to leave the Republican presidential race, although a week before he had hoped to revive his campaign in the South Carolina primary; says he will back former rival Mitt Romney. (M)a
author: JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY; Michael D. Shear contributed reporting from Washington
headline: Huntsman Set To End His Bid; Backs Romney

abstract: Caucus column; social issues that are important to southern Republicans were widely expected to be the centerpiece of the South Carolina primary, but Mitt Romney's opponents have put aside those issues in order to attack his tenure at Bain Capital. (M)a
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: An Unexpected Focus Before the Next Primary

abstract: Political Memo; Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has benefited from a shifting field of opponents in the primary contest, none of which has the combination of meticulous planning, governing, campaign experience and money that has propelled Romney into a commanding position heading into South Carolina. Photo (M)a
author: JOHN HARWOOD
headline: Romney Advantage: Unequally Matched Rivals

abstract: With for-profit colleges under siege in Washington over accusations that they defraud students, Mitt Romneys endorsement of them puts him in the middle of a political debate.
author: ERIC LICHTBLAU; Toby Lyles contributed research
headline: Romney Praises A Business Run By A Big Donor

abstract: Evangelical leaders pursue a last-ditch effort to exert influence in the Republican presidential primary race, voting to support Rick Santorum in the hopes of undercutting Mitt Romney's march to the nomination; more than 100 influential Christian conservatives voted overwhelmingly to support Santorum, but it is unclear what effect that support will have, if any, on the race. Photo (M)
author: ERIK ECKHOLM and JEFF ZELENY; Erik Eckholm reported from Brenham, Tex., and Jeff Zeleny from Mount Pleasant, S.C. Robbie Brown contributed reporting from Sumter, S.C
headline: Evangelicals, Seeking Unity, Back Santorum

abstract: Mitt Romney faces a South Carolina electorate in which 60 percent of Republican voters are evangelical Christians, many of whom have been taught that the Mormon faith is apostasy; basic differences about scripture, the afterlife and the nature of God have led many Christians to conclude that Mormons cannot be considered Christian. Photo (M)
author: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
headline: The Theological Differences Behind Evangelical Unease With Romney

abstract: Political Memo; the lead up to the South Carolina primary has been defined by fierce attacks on Mitt Romney's tenure at Bain Capital, sparing him what otherwise might have been an inquisition on social issues and his Mormon faith. Photos (M)y
author: JEFF ZELENY; Ashley Parker contributed reporting from Hilton Head, S.C
headline: Advisers See an Upside in Criticism of Romney's Time at Bain Capital

abstract: Mitt Romney's Republican rivals are using the 1992 closing of a Gaffney, SC, factory by Bain Capital, private equity firm led by Romney, to portray him as a job-destroying robber baron; the problem is that few in the town even remember the plant, let alone the devastation that its closing is alleged to have caused; the development testifies to the impact of the campaigns' opposition research and their willingness to exploit a convenient storyline. Map, Photos (M)
author: KIM SEVERSON
headline: Town, Cast as Romney's Victim, Says, 'Huh?'

abstract: Text and assessment of television ad released by Mitt Romney's presidential campaign in South Carolina, which responds to growing attacks on his career at Bain Capital. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Images and Praise Shine a Flattering Light on Romney's Business Past

abstract: Republican presidential contender Newt Gingrich asks the group behind film portraying Mitt Romney as a heartless job killer change the film or withdraw it; pro-Gingrich 'super PAC' makes no move to alter the work, instead demanding that Romney answer a series of questions before it makes any changes to the film. (M)
author: JIM RUTENBERG, TRIP GABRIEL and MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: In Reversal, Gingrich Calls for Withdrawal of Film Attacking Romney and Bain

abstract: Conservative Christian leaders acknowledge that they are unlikely to agree on a single alternative candidate to Mitt Romney until after the South Carolina primary on Jan 21, if then; original dream of coalescing around one candidate of the religious right, Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum or Rick Perry, is unrealistic for now, several leaders say. Photo (M)
author: ERIK ECKHOLM
headline: Evangelicals Hope South Carolina or Florida Winnows Republican Field

abstract: Mitt Romney's carefully tended network of Republican donors has been rendered functionally less important by 'super PACs,' through which a handful of wealthy individuals are financing a multimillion-dollar advertising barrage to assail his record and prop up his opponents; his rival Republicans have little incentive to drop out, knowing that their support from super PACs and Internet contributions from grass-roots supporters can keep them in the race long after they would have remained viable in earlier eras. Photo (M)
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and JIM RUTENBERG
headline: PACs' Aid Allows Romney's Rivals to Extend Race

abstract: The Caucus; John R Bolton, ambassador to the United Nations under President George W Bush, endorses Mitt Romney for president. (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Endorsement Watch: John Bolton Backs Romney

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney, who polls better among affluent voters, faces increased challenges as the Republican nominating contest transitions to economically struggling states of South Carolina, Nevada and Florida. Charts (S)
author: DAVID LEONHARDT
headline: Race Moves to Weaker Economies

abstract: A day after his drubbing of the Republican field, Mitt Romney assailed the angry attacks about his work for Bain Capital and urged his opponents to settle on what he called a new course.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Trip Gabriel contributed reporting from Rock Hill, S.C
headline: Romney Says N.H. Results Show Attacks on Him Failed

abstract: Poll conducted by the Pew Forum on Religion finds that many Mormons feel uneasy about attention that has been drawn to their religion by Mitt Romney, saying they are misunderstood and unaccepted in the American mainstream; majority of respondents do say that acceptance of Mormonism is on the rise, and that the American people are ready to elect a Mormon president. Graph (M)
author: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
headline: Mormons Uneasy in the Spotlight

abstract: Political Memo; conservative strategists worry that Mitt Romney's pro-business message may not play as well as it has in previous elections with conservatives, who are increasingly dubious of unregulated enterprise, especially on Wall Street. Photo (M)
author: JOHN HARWOOD
headline: A Blurring of the Lines in the Populist vs. Capitalist Debate

abstract: Newt Gingrich and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas attacked Mitt Romneys character, his business record and his past views on abortion.
author: JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY; Richard A. Oppel Jr. contributed reporting from Lexington, S.C
headline: Republican Rivals Batter Romney in South Carolina

abstract: Democrats are delighted by Republican attacks on Mitt Romney, saying they will end up assisting President Obama's re-election effort. (M)
author: JACKIE CALMES
headline: With Recent Criticism, Romney's Rivals Bring a Smile to the White House

abstract: Many voters in the New Hampshire's Republican primary, before handing Mitt Romney a victory, say they made their minds up only at the last minute; say their decisions were based on economic concerns and, in many cases, pragmatism, with the aim of defeating Pres Obama in November. Chart, Graph, Photos (M)l
author: ABBY GOODNOUGH and MARJORIE CONNELLY; Reporting was contributed by Jess Bidgood in Salem and Laconia, N.H.; Nicholas Confessore in Portsmouth, N.H.; and Will Storey in Bedford, N.H
headline: Before Handing Romney a Victory, Many Voters Spent Weeks Wavering

abstract: Republican presidential hopeful Ron Paul finishes a strong second in New Hampshire primary, which in many ways is the more telling outcome in a race where Mitt Romney's dominance was never in doubt; outcome seems to give Paul, often dismissed as a protest candidate, reason to extend his campaign. Graphs, Photo (M)0
author: TRIP GABRIEL; Reporting was contributed by Richard A. Oppel Jr. in Leesville, S.C., and Katharine Q. Seelye, Marjorie Connelly and Michael D. Shear in Manchester
headline: A Victory, of Sorts, for Second-Place Finisher Paul in New Hampshire

abstract: Conservative television commentators and news outlets covering Republican presidential hopeful Mitt Romney's win in the New Hampshire primary suggest that South Carolina will pose a more important test; while their comments are not outwardly negative, they implicitly urge TV and Web viewers to stay tuned. (M)2
author: BRIAN STELTER; David Carr and Noam Cohen contributed reporting
headline: With a Fast and Anticipated Result, TV Analysts Shift Focus to South Carolina

abstract: Advisers to Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, stung by unexpectedly fierce attacks from Republican rivals on his career as a corporate buyout specialist, are scrambling to avoid a nasty battle over his business record before it does him lasting damage; rebut criticisms by telling stories of winners in the world of private equity. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER; Nicholas Confessore contributed reporting from Manchester, and Richard A. Oppel Jr. from Columbia, S.C
headline: Advisers Work to Put Positive Spin on Romney's Career in Corporate Buyouts

abstract: Mitt Romney wins the Republican presidential primary in New Hampshire, turning back ferocious assault from rivals who sought to disqualify him in the eyes of conservatives; wins by double-digit margin that validates his strategy; candidates who had hoped to use the primary to emerge as his leading rival fared poorly, leaving a fractured Republican opposition. Photo (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY; Reporting was contributed by Trip Gabriel and Nicholas Confessore in Manchester, N.H., and Dalia Sussman and Allison Kopicki in New York
headline: Romney Is Winner In New Hampshire Blunting Attacks

abstract: Private equity industry comes under scrutiny as Mitt Romney's Republican rivals attack his record at investment firm Bain Capital; his opponents accuse such firms of carving up companies and cutting jobs; attacks unnerve many buyout executives, especially those who have long used their fortunes to support the Republican Party. Photo (M)
author: PETER LATTMAN and ANNIE LOWREY
headline: As Romney Campaign Advances, Private Equity Becomes Part of the Debate

abstract: Mitt Romney, who for years has been relentlessly cultivating local officials, finds his efforts bearing fruit as his allies in New Hampshire roll out their endorsements, help him raise money and provide access to their local get-out-the-vote networks. Photo (M)a
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: For Romney, Close Ties To Officials Bear Fruit

abstract: FiveThirtyEight blog develops measure of poll volatility that calculates how much the Republican presidential candidates' polling shifted month to month during the primaries, above and beyond random variance; chart shows that Mitt Romney and Ron Paul have remarkably stable support, which may be due to their strong financial backing and well-planned field operations in the early-voting states. Chart (M)d
author: NATE SILVER and MICAH COHEN
headline: Ground Game Can Firm Up a Candidate's Footing

abstract: South Carolina is fast becoming an early proving ground for the Republican candidates in a volatile and unpredictable political season; question remains whether Tea Party supporters will choose moderate frontrunner Mitt Romney or coalesce around a more conservative candidate like Rick Santorum. Photo (M)
author: SUSAN SAULNY
headline: In South Carolina, Hopes Of Passing a Crucial Test

abstract: The attacks on Mitt Romney over his role at Bain Capital, a corporate buyout firm, came as his lead in New Hampshire appeared to be slipping.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Richard A. Oppel, Ashley Parker, Jeff Zeleny, Jim Rutenberg, Marjorie Connelly and Abby Goodnough contributed reporting from New Hampshire
headline: Romney Waves Away Opponents' Intensifying Attacks

abstract: Republican candidates campaigning in New Hampshire seek to slow Mitt Romney's front-runner status and raise doubts about his electability by branding him as a job-killing corporate villain; attacks are so piercing that some leading Republicans urge the candidates to back off. Photos (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG; Reporting was contributed by Michael Barbaro and Trip Gabriel in Manchester, N.H.; Richard A. Oppel Jr. in Anderson, S.C.; Ashley Parker in Hudson, N.H.; and Katharine Q. Seelye in Somersworth, N.H
headline: On Primary Eve, Rivals Try to Put Romney on Defensive

abstract: Super PAC supporting Republican presidential hopeful Newt Gingrich plans to run advertisements financed by casino mogul Sheldon Adelson that attack Mitt Romney's work with private equity firm Bain Capital, using clips from an anti-Romney film; Democrats say they plan to make Romney's history at Bain a case against him if he wins the Republican nomination but issue also emerges in Republican primary, reflecting depth of public anger about the economy. Photos (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: PAC Ads to Hit Romney's Role At Equity Firm

abstract: Republican race for president splinters along two distinct tracts in New Hampshire debate, as rivals line up against Mitt Romney and engage him in some of the most pointed exchanges of the campaign; Romney remains solid favorite there two days before the first primary of the Republican nominating process but candidates who lag behind him compete to outlast one another through the next few nominating contests. Photo (M)
author: JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY
headline: A Sharper Edge For Republicans As Voting Nears

abstract: "Jon M Huntsman Jr has bet his entire presidential campaign on a strong showing in the New Hampshire primaries;" candidate has faced many challenges in the campaign, including Mitt Romney's solid lead and the surging popularity of Rick Santorum and Rep Ron Paul, but his greatest obstacle has been a shortage of campaign funds.
author: JIM RUTENBERG
headline: Huntsman, Out of Options, Bets It All on New Hampshire

abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column contends that the selection of Eric Ulrich as Mitt Romney's campaign chairman in New York City seems intended to convince New Yorkers that not all the Republican presidential candidates are extremists; Ulrich is youngest member of City Council and centrist Republican with working class roots.
author: GINIA BELLAFANTE
headline: Mitts Young Republican, Up From the Streets

abstract: Four of Mitt Romney's sons--Tagg, Matt, Josh and Craig--are out on the campaign trail stumping for their father and, in the process, offering the public a glimpse of their own lives. Photos (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from Des Moines
headline: Romney Times Four

abstract: Mitt Romney emerges unscathed from a crucial debate in New Hampshire in advance of the state's primary as his Republican rivals engage in a spirited fight to determine which of them would become Romney's most formidable opponent. Photo (M)g
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG
headline: At G.O.P. Debate, Romeny Eludes Rivals' Attacks

abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column contends that the selection of Eric Ulrich as Mitt Romney's campaign chairman in New York City seems intended to convince New Yorkers that not all the Republican presidential candidates are extremists; Ulrich is youngest member of City Council and centrist Republican with working class roots. Photos (M)/
author: GINIA BELLAFANTE
headline: Mitt's Young Republican, Up From the Streets

abstract: Newt Gingrich is receiving a much-needed boost from billionaire Sheldon Adelson, who has donated $5 million to a super PAC backing Gingrich's presidential bid; Gingrich and the other Republican candidates are making their final appeals in hopes of catching up with frontrunner Mitt Romney as the New Hampshire primary nears. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE; Reporting was contributed by Katharine Q. Seelye from Amherst, N.H.; Trip Gabriel and Richard A. Oppel Jr. from Concord, N.H.; Abby Goodnough from North Haverhill, N.H.; and Jeff Zeleny from Manchester
headline: As New Hampshire Primary Looms, Donor Boosts Gingrich

abstract: Mitt Romney's campaign statement that government consumes 37 percent of the economy's output is in reality based on the combined size of the federal, state and local governments; Congressional Budget Office has reported that federal government spending alone in 2010 was equivalent to only 23.8 percent of the gross domestic product. (S)
author: JACKIE CALMES
headline: Government's Share

abstract: Political Memo; Republican winner of the Iowa caucuses has fallen short in New Hampshire in every competitive contest since 1980, a trend that Mitt Romney is trying his best to break. Chart (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY; Ashley Parker contributed reporting
headline: Romney Advantages Could Prove Disadvantageous

abstract: Caucus column; Peter C Schaumber, a top adviser to Mitt Romney's presidential campaign, found during his tenure at the National Labor Relations Board that two companies controlled by Bain Capital had violated labor rules; Romney, who helped start Bain Capital, has repeatedly excoriated members of the board. (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Once Critical of Bain, But Now Advising Romney

abstract: Evangelical Christian leaders are intensifying discussion about jointly backing an alternative candidate to Mitt Romney for the Republican nomination for president. Photos (M)
author: ERIK ECKHOLM
headline: Evangelicals Step Up Efforts to Unite on an Alternative to Romney

abstract: Political Memo; Mitt Romney's suggestion that he draws inspiration from the country's founders while President Obama seeks a 'European-style welfare state,' among other things, could be a risky comparison. Photo (M)
author: JOHN HARWOOD
headline: Romney Facing Risks Left and Right

abstract: Caucus column; Newt Gingrich releases new television ad painting his rival Mitt Romney's economic plans as timid compared with his own; ad uses quotations critical of Romney from the Wall Street Journal and Forbes and goes further than any previous effort by Gingrich, who has been struggling to win over New Hampshire voters. Photo (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Advertising: Gingrich Takes a Harsher Tone

abstract: A slightly smaller field shifted its attention to New Hampshire and South Carolina, the next chances for someone not named Romney to challenge the perceived front-runner.
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE; Jeff Zeleny contributed reporting from Manchester, N.H
headline: Republican Race Moves Beyond Iowa

abstract: Political Memo; highly choreographed appearance by Sen John McCain to endorse Mitt Romney's presidential campaign is marked by awkwardness and unspoken coolness between the two men; publicity bid, following Romney's narrow victory at the Iowa caucuses, is further hampered by pointed and critical questions from audience members; Romney's public stiffness and lack of warmth is considered a significant impediment. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER; Jonathan Weisman contributed reporting
headline: On Stage, an Awkward Reminder of Personal Rifts in G.O.P.

abstract: Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney displays his organizational and financial muscle in New Hampshire as Rick Santorum's campaign struggles to keep up with its new top-tier status; accepts endorsement of onetime bitter rival Sen John McCain. Photo, Charts (M)1
author: JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY; Erik Eckholm contributed reporting from New York
headline: Romney Showing Financial Muscle For Next Round

abstract: Newt Gingrich, following fourth-place bruising in the Iowa caucuses, immediately begins fulfilling vow to take on Gov Mitt Romney and Rep Ron Paul more aggressively; anti-Gingrich ads aired by the Romney and Paul campaigns helped derail Gingrich's surge in the lead-up to the caucuses. Photo (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: After a Red-Eye, Gingrich Reloads

abstract: Mitt Romney won the endorsement of Senator John McCain, his archrival from 2008, and Rick Santorum faced the challenge of broadening his organization on the fly.
author: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and JEFF ZELENY; Reporting was contributed by A.G. Sulzberger in Alton, Iowa; Susan Saulny in Clive, Iowa; and Dalia Sussman and Allison Kopecki in New York
headline: McCain Backs Romney After Santorum's Surge in Iowa

abstract: Caucus column; Iowa caucuses will not hold recount despite Mitt Romney's razor-thin victory because there is no legal provision for one; caucus votes are in reality non-binding guidelines for state Republicans as they hold local and state conventions to elect convention delegates. (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: A Close Finish, But Still No Recount

abstract: Mitt Romney's quest to lock down the Republican nomination with a commanding finish in the Iowa caucuses is spoiled by the surging candidacy of Rick Santorum, who fights him to a draw on a shoestring budget by winning over conservatives skeptical of Romney; the two candidates were separated by only a sliver of votes and the outcome offers Santorum a chance to emerge as the alternative to Romney. Photo (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY; Reporting was contributed by A.G. Sulzberger in Alton, Iowa; Susan Saulny in Clive, Iowa; and Dalia Sussman and Allison Kopecki in New York
headline: Dueling Romney, Santorum Surges In Iowa Caucuses

abstract: Mitt Romney is far ahead in the polls for the New Hampshire primary, leading other candidates to turn their focus to the South Carolina primary 11 days later; the southern state is emerging as an early crucible in an unpredictable political season. Chart (M)t
author: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
headline: New Hampshire Now Optional for Some

abstract: Newt Gingrich, with his Republican presidential candidacy battered by negative campaign ads and a disappointing showing in the Iowa caucuses, is adjusting his strategy to rescue his ailing campaign, aggressively swatting back at challenger Mitt Romney. Photos (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL; Nicholas Confessore and Michael D. Shear contributed reporting from Des Moines
headline: Frustrated Gingrich Lashes Back at Romney and Awaits the Next Round

abstract: Race between Ron Paul, Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum in the Iowa Republican caucuses appeared at first too close to call, catching nation's television news anchors by surprise. (M)
author: BRIAN STELTER
headline: Tight Race Catches TV Anchors By Surprise

abstract: Republican presidential candidates Mitt Romney, Rick Santorum, Ron Paul, Michele Bachmann, Newt Gingrich and Rick Perry, on last day of campaigning before the caucuses, implore Iowans to turn out for them.
author: THE NEW YORK TIMES
headline: On Eve of First Voting of 12, a Last Pitch in Iowa

abstract: Republican presidential candidates Mitt Romney, Rick Santorum, Ron Paul, Michele Bachmann, Newt Gingrich and Rick Perry, on last day of campaigning before the caucuses, implore Iowans to turn out for them. Photos (L)
author: ASHLEY PARKER, JEREMY W. PETERS, RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr., SUSAN SAULNY, TRIP GABRIEL and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: On Eve of First Voting of 2012, Urgent Appeals

abstract: Outcome of the Iowa caucuses, curious political ritual that is about to open yet another race for the White House, will set a tone for the race after a yearlong prelude that has been off the charts in its unpredictability; Republican candidates enter a final day of frenzied campaigning, with top runners Mitt Romney, Rick Santorum and Rep Ron Paul rushing to claim victory as the contest then moves to New Hampshire. Photos (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG
headline: Twisting Race Hits First Turn As Iowa Votes

abstract: Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum emerges as the latest in a rotating cast of surging alternatives to Mitt Romney days before the Iowa caucuses, just as Romney seeks to convert his tentative standing in the polls into a first-place finish; outcome of the caucuses could be an indicator of whether Romney is succeeding in rallying conservatives behind him or whether he faces months of struggle to win delegates and resolve the rifts within the Republican Party. Photos (M)
author: JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY; Reporting was contributed by Jill Abramson from Council Bluffs, Iowa, and Michael Barbaro and Sarah Wheaton from Des Moines
headline: In Iowa, Romney Fights to Become Caucus Favorite

abstract: Republican presidential candidates are making final appeals to Iowa voters as caucus draws near; volatility of race is underscored by latest Des Moines Register poll showing Mitt Romney and Ron Paul essentially tied for the lead with Rick Santorum gaining momentum close behind. Photos (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG; Katharine Q. Seelye contributed reporting from Hampton, N.H.; Trip Gabriel from Council Bluffs, Iowa; and Susan Saulny from Urbandale, Iowa
headline: Last-Minute Scramble As Caucus Night Nears

abstract: Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has taken to quoting from patriotic songs during campaign events, and expounding on their meaning. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Quotes His Favorite Patriotic Songs and Offers Voters an Interpretation

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney attends Memorial Day tribute with Sen John McCain in San Diego, Calif, in attempt to win support of veterans, who strongly supported McCain during the 2008 presidential race. Photo (M)2
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: With a War Hero at His Side, Romney Courts Veterans

abstract: Mitt Romney, campaigning in Last Vegas, expected to at last formally claim the Republican presidential nomination with a victory in the Texas primary, but instead fends off questions about comments made by supporter Donald Trump over Pres Obama's Hawaiian birth certificate. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER; Reporting was contributed by Michael D. Shear from Washington, Nicholas Confessore from New York and Michael Barbaro from Las Vegas
headline: Romney, on His Big Day, Finds Himself Upstaged

abstract: Mitt Romney condemns Pres Obama's foreign policy following the massacre of more than 100 civilians in Syria; calls for the United States to work with its partners to arm Syrian opposition groups, proposal that has split the Republican party. Photo (M)i
author: MARK LANDLER; Jonathan Weisman contributed reporting from Beaufort, S.C
headline: Romney Calls for Action, But His Party Is Divided

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney attends Memorial Day tribute with Sen John McCain in San Diego, Calif, in attempt to win support of veterans, who strongly supported McCain during the 2008 presidential race. Photo (M)2
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: With a War Hero at His Side, Romney Courts Veterans

abstract: Rudolph W Giuliani, Sen John McCain and Newt Gingrich reframe their past criticisms of Mitt Romney's tenure at Bain Capital, seeking to counter attack ads by the Obama campaign; all three men are former Romney rivals who now openly support the candidate. (M)0
author: BRIAN KNOWLTON
headline: Romney's Former Rivals Speak Out on Bain Attacks

abstract: "Lawsuit, since settled, offers a glimpse into dressage, the chosen sport of Mitt Romneys wife, and into the elite world of expensive horses;" Ann Romney returned to horseback riding, a sport she loved as a girl, after receiving a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis in 1998; as she immersed herself in the riding over the last dozen years, she relied on Jan Ebeling as a trusted tutor and horse scout; in her, he found a deep-pocketed patron.
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: In Rarefied Sport, a View of the Romneys World

abstract: A lawsuit, since settled, offers a glimpse into dressage, the chosen sport of Mitt Romneys wife, and into the elite world of expensive horses.
author: TRIP GABRIEL; Jodi Kantor and Stephanie Saul contributed reporting
headline: In Rarefied Sport, a View of the Romneys' World

abstract: Jim Wilson, a 69-year-old former life insurance salesman, has devoted himself to following presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney around the country, driving a pickup truck festooned with giant Romney for President posters; Wilson has become unexpectedly valuable to the campaign, helping with events and offering a charming counterpoint to a sometimes awkward Romney. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: On the Road For Romney, 40,000 Miles And Counting

abstract: Mitt Romney's tenure at Bain Capital has become a complex campaign issue, as the Obama camp tries to use it underscore Romney's image as an out-of-touch multimillionaire; Romney is attempting to undercut this message, saying his private sector experience has equipped him to manage the economy. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from Philadelphia
headline: Both Campaigns Seize on Romney's Years at Bain

abstract: Caucus column; Vice President Joseph R Biden Jr continues the assault on presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's experience running Bain Capital, saying it does not qualify him to be president; former Gov Edward G Rendell of Pennsylvania expresses concerns about the attacks. (M)
author: PETER BAKER
headline: Attack on Bain Goes On, But Doubts Linger

abstract: Mitt Romney shifts his campaign focus to education, calling for poor and disabled students to be able to use federal funds to attend any public, private or online school they choose; characterizes the poor performance of minority students as a major issue of civil rights. Photo (M)/
author: TRIP GABRIEL; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting
headline: Romney Calls Education 'Civil Rights Issue of Our Era' and Urges Shift

abstract: While many Mormons are rooting for Mitt Romney, minorities within the community are becoming more assertive.
author: SUSAN SAULNY
headline: For Black Mormons, a Political Choice Like No Other

abstract: "People close to Mitt Romney insist that his Mormonism is a driving force in his life, despite fact that he rarely mentions his faith on the campaign trail;" Romney's long history with the Mormon church includes missionary work and strict adherence to its laws and dogmas (Series: The Long Run).
author: JODI KANTOR
headline: Romneys Faith, Silent but Deep

abstract: Script by Etan Cohen, writer of movie Men in Black 3, imagines presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's vetting process for his choice of running mate. Drawings (M)
author: ETAN COHEN
headline: Mitt Makes A Friend

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney comes close to matching Pres Obama's fundraising in April, raising $40.1 million to the president's $43.6 million; boost is partly attributable to Romney's financing alliance with the Republican National Committee. (M)1
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Romney Keeps Pace In the Money Race

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney, in campaign speech, discloses that he and his wife Ann are considering moving to Florida during their retirement, citing the state's low tax rates. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Unbeatable Combination: Low Taxes, and Sunshine

abstract: Mitt Romney's Republican presidential campaign and its supporters view New Hampshire as a real opportunity to pry four electoral votes away from Pres Obama, who won the state decisively in 2008. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Michael Barbaro reported from Hillsborough, N.H., and Michael D. Shear from Washington
headline: Romney Supporters Hopeful About New Hampshire

abstract: Political Memo; campaign aides to Mitt Romney apologize after attempting to keep the traveling press corps from documenting the candidate's rope-line interactions at an event in Florida; Romney has committed several gaffes while chatting casually with supporters during handshake sessions. Photo (M)t
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER; Michael Barbaro reported from St. Petersburg, and Ashley Parker from New York
headline: Romney Camp Tries to Limit Reporters' Access, and Rope Line Ruckus Erupts

abstract: Iowa, swing state with relatively low unemployment rate, may be an important laboratory for presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's broad effort to lay the blame for nation's ongoing economic distress at Pres Obama's feet; Romney is pressing hard to win Iowa's six electoral votes, which Obama won in 2008. Photo (M)y
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Michael Barbaro reported from Des Moines, and Michael D. Shear from Washington
headline: Iowa, Again, Serves as Proving Ground for Romney

abstract: Political Memo: report by Washington Post that Mitt Romney had bullied a fellow student while at prep school in the 1960s could do major damage to his image during the critical period between the end of the primary season and the formal start of the general election campaign at the conventions, when presidential challengers are most likely to be defined on terms other than their own. Photos (M)
author: RICHARD W. STEVENSON
headline: Political Memo: A Post-Primary Window to Define a Challenger

abstract: Mitt Romney and Pres Obama trade barbs over their contrasting Medicare proposals, each arguing that his opponent's policies would end the popular government-run health insurance program as it now exists; Romney, whose plan calls for limiting the government's current open-ended financial commitment to Medicare, says that he offers not just a policy change, but a dramatic change in perspective and philosophy. Photo (M)
author: ROBERT PEAR
headline: Romney Medicare Plan Draws a Stark Contrast

abstract: "Mitt Romney delivers graduation speech at conservative Liberty University, seeking to quell concerns among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of faith and Christian values in public life;" Romney makes the case that he is bound theologically and politically to Christian beliefs, but does not mention his own Mormon faith.
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Tells Evangelicals Their Values Are His, Too

abstract: Mitt Romney delivers graduation speech at conservative Liberty University, seeking to quell concerns among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of faith and Christian values in public life; Romney makes the case that he is bound theologically and politically to Christian beliefs, but does not mention his own Mormon faith. Photos (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Assures Evangelicals That Their Values Are His, Too

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's declaration that Russia is America's top geopolitical adversary caused many Democrats, some Republicans and the Russians themselves to suggest that Romney is stuck in a cold war mind-set; Romney has long held hawkish views on Russia, which has stirred debate in the Republican Party and in his own close circle of advisers. Photo (M)
author: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
headline: Romney's Adversarial View of Russia Stirs Debate

abstract: Caucus column; 'super PAC' backing Mitt Romney's presidential campaign releases ad in advance of Mother's Day that revives the criticism that Democratic strategist Hilary Rosen leveled against Ann Romney and links it to the Obama campaign; ad is part of fierce battle for female voters. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Ad Defends Ann Romney, Then Goes on Attack

abstract: Mitt Romney responds to allegations that as a teenager he harassed a prep school classmate who later came out as gay, a day after Pres Obama endorsed gay marriage; Romney apologizes for pranks he may have been responsible for during his high school years, while asserting that he does not remember the specific incident. Photos (M)o
author: ASHLEY PARKER  and JODI KANTOR
headline: Bullying Story Spurs Apology From Romney

abstract: Mitt Romney reaffirms his belief that marriage should be restricted to heterosexual couples following Pres Obama's endorsement of marriage equality; Romney's language leaves open many questions about what his vision of legally recognizable gay unions would encompass. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Romney Reaffirms Opposition to Marriage, or Unions, for Gay Couples

abstract: Caucus column; likely Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney tells a Cleveland television station that he deserves some credit for the automobile industry's recovery, despite the fact that he opposed the bailout. Photo (M)1
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: The Auto Industry: Taking 'a Lot of Credit'

abstract: Caucus column; former Republican presidential contender Rick Santorum offers late-night, tepid e-mail endorsement of his onetime rival Mitt Romney for the presidential nomination. (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: An Endorsement In the Dead of Night

abstract: Caucus column; likely Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney disagrees with comment made by a supporter at a campaign event in Euclid, Ohio, that Pres Obama should be tried for treason. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Rejects Treason Comment

abstract: Caucus column; Rick Santorum tells his supporters that he is endorsing Mitt Romney for president. (M)n
author: JENNIFER PRESTON
headline: Santorum Backs Romney in Race

abstract: Caucus column on Rep Ron Paul's ongoing presidential campaign; notes that while Paul is unlikely to dislodge Mitt Romney as the Republican nominee, he could have an impact at his party's convention. Photo (M)m
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Still in the Race, And Plotting a Path To the Convention

abstract: Caucus column; Republican presidential contender Mitt Romney's eldest son Tagg announces the birth of twin sons, born with the help of a surrogate. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Expanding His Base: Twin Grandsons for Romney

abstract: New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg, in his weekly radio show, offers no details on whether he is supporting Mitt Romney or Pres Obama for president. (M)/
author: MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM
headline: Mayor Says Little of Romney Visit

abstract: Caucus column; Rep Michele Bachmann endorses Mitt Romney for president. Photo (M)5
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Endorsing Romney: Bachmann's 'Easy' Choice

abstract: Many of Mitt Romney's Republican presidential rivals have emerged from the contest in significant debt, and some with tarnished political reputations; phenomenon belies common wisdom that even a failed presidential bid can increase a candidate's name recognition, pave the way to lucrative speaking fees and help with a re-election effort. Photos (M)
author: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
headline: After Primary Losses, Legacies of Debt and Strained Reputations

abstract: Aides to Mitt Romney insist they did everything to keep Richard Grenell, gay political strategist, from resigning; on one level, his short-lived and rocky tenure with the campaign is the story of halting attempts to manage Romney's relationship with the conservative wing of the party; on another level, it is also about how a fast-growing campaign, operating under the sharp glare of a general election, failed to spot potential hazards of a high-profile appointment. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO, HELENE COOPER and ASHLEY PARKER; Jeff Zeleny and Richard A. Oppel Jr. contributed reporting from Washington
headline: Romney Camp Stirred Storm Over Gay Aide

abstract: Richard Grenell, openly gay and longtime Republican foreign policy spokesman hired in April by Mitt Romney's presidential campaign, quits amid pressure by some Republicans who criticized his appointment. Photo (M)
author: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and HELENE COOPER; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from New Haven, Conn
headline: Romney Foreign Policy Spokesman Quits

abstract: Solamere Capital, private equity firm founded by presidential candidate Mitt Romney's son Tagg Romney and Romney campaign fund-raiser Spencer Zwick, is in line to collect at least $16.8 million in fees over six years, despite a challenging fund-raising climate; Tagg Romney and Zwick dispute allegations that they cashed in on their political connections, arguing that Solamere, like any fund, has had to persuade investors on its merits. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL LUO and JULIE CRESWELL
headline: Ties to Romney '08 Helped Fuel an Equity Firm

abstract: Caucus column; Restore Our Future, a pro-Romney super PAC, scrubs its YouTube account of negative ads against Newt Gingrich and Rick Santorum in an apparent offering of peace. (M)
author: NICK CORASANITI
headline: G.O.P. Campaign: An Online Peace Offering

abstract: "Representative Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin, has become perhaps the most influential policy maker in the Republican Party, its de facto head of economic policy, intent on a fundamental transformation of the federal government;" outside of Mitt Romney, Ryan may be the partys most important figure; he is among the handful of people most often mentioned as both a 2012 vice-presidential nominee and a future presidential candidate (Series: The Ticket).
author: JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: Ryans Rise From Follower to G.O.P. Trailblazer

abstract: Tagg Romney, Mitt Romneys eldest son, and Spencer Zwick, a Romney campaign fund-raiser, turned to wealthy campaign donors for investments in their firm.
author: MICHAEL LUO and JULIE CRESWELL
headline: Ties to Romney in '08 Helped Fuel Equity Firm

abstract: Caucus column notes that Rep Michele Bachmann, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich continue to delay endorsing Mitt Romney for president, leading Republican Party insiders to wonder what game they are playing. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: When Rivals Concede But Are in No Rush To Add Endorsement

abstract: Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, is trying to shift the debate away from his hawkish stance on immigration to focus on jobs and the economy in key battleground state of Florida; state is home to growing numbers of non-Cuban Hispanics who are receptive to Republicans' economic and social views, but are reluctant to back the party in part because of its stance on illegal immigration. Photos (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Crucial to Romney, Florida's Latino Voters Are Wary of Him, Too

abstract: Caucus column; Ann Romney, who was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1998, announces that she experienced a temporary onset of symptoms in the lead-up to the Super Tuesday primaries. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Battling On: Ann Romney's M.S. Scare

abstract: Vice Pres Joseph R Biden Jr, in speech in New York City, paints Mitt Romney as a cold-war relic whose foreign policy would revive the dangerous go-it-alone ethos of the Bush administration; Obama campaign believes it has a distinct advantage on national security, which is unusual for a Democratic incumbent. Photo (M)1
author: MARK LANDLER; Richard A. Oppel Jr. contributed reporting
headline: Romney Uses 'Cold War Prism,' Biden Says in Foreign Policy Attack

abstract: Newt Gingrich agrees to formally end his presidential campaign, ending an improbable effort that capitalized on new campaign finance regulations and conservative ambivalence about Mitt Romney; pledges to throw his weight behind Romney so that Republicans can retake the presidency.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Yielding to the Real World, Gingrich Tells Romney Hell Quit the Race

abstract: Republican Party leaders urge Mitt Romney to balance his attacks on Pres Obama with an optimistic conservatism that will inspire the party's base, appeal to independents and set out a governing agenda should he win. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Allies Urge Romney to Shift to Positive Campaign

abstract: Newt Gingrich agrees to formally end his presidential campaign, ending an improbable effort that capitalized on new campaign finance regulations and conservative ambivalence about Mitt Romney; pledges to throw his weight behind Romney so that Republicans can retake the presidency. Photos (M)/
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Yielding to 'the Real World,' Gingrich Tells Romney He'll Quit the Race

abstract: Mitt Romney effectively assumes the helm of the Republican Party after five primary victories in the Northeast solidify his status as presidential nominee-in-waiting; he receives a significant boost in delegates from New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Delaware.
author: ASHLEY PARKER and JEFF ZELENY
headline: With 5 More Victories, Romney Focuses on the Fall

abstract: Mitt Romney effectively assumes the helm of the Republican Party after five primary victories in the Northeast solidify his status as presidential nominee-in-waiting; he receives a significant boost in delegates from New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Delaware. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER and JEFF ZELENY; Ashley Parker reported from Manchester, and Jeff Zeleny from Washington. Jennifer Steinhauer contributed reporting from Washington
headline: With 5 More Victories, Romney's Focus Is Fall

abstract: New York's Republican presidential primary appears to be an electoral afterthought, after Rick Santorum's exit from the race and Mitt Romney's rise to the level of presumptive nominee; at stake are New York's 96 delegates.
author: THOMAS KAPLAN
headline: Not Much Suspense Likely in New York G.O.P. Primary

abstract: Sen Marco Rubio of Florida, who had campaigned with likely Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney in Pennsylvania, joins a list of possible vice-presidential running mates, which includes several governors and lawmakers. Photo (M)0
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Rubio Is Latest Possible Running Mate to Join Romney on the Campaign Trail

abstract: New York's Republican presidential primary appears to be an electoral afterthought, after Rick Santorum's exit from the race and Mitt Romney's rise to the level of presumptive nominee; at stake are New York's 96 delegates. (M)
author: THOMAS KAPLAN
headline: New York G.O.P. Primary Now a Footnote

abstract: Caucus column; primaries in Connecticut, Delaware, New York, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island offer Mitt Romney the opportunity to make official his de facto status as the Republican presidential nominee, and to shore up fundraising and endorsements as the general contest approaches. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Five More Primaries, And a Pivotal Moment For Romney's Campaign

abstract: Edward Rothstein Critic's Notebook describes the exhibits at the Church History Museum of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Salt Lake City; observes that more attention is being paid to the church and its beliefs, due to Mitt Romney's candidacy for president; notes that the museum offers considerable insight into Mormon culture and some of the tensions in the young religion. Photos (M)
author: EDWARD ROTHSTEIN
headline: Go West, Young Religion: Mormonism on Exhibit

abstract: Republican presidential contender Mitt Romney's top aides plan to move quickly after upcoming primaries in New York and Pennsylvania to integrate the campaign's growing staff with the Republican National Committee, in effort to avoid logistical stumbles that have hampered past nominees. (M)a
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and TRIP GABRIEL; Ashley Parker contributed reporting from Boston
headline: Romney Aides Are Set to Fold Republican Party Apparatus Into Campaign

abstract: Caucus column; Sales at bakery in Bethel, Pa, surge despite the fact that presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney compared the bakery's cookies to 7-Eleven. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: A Baker's Five Dozen: Making Hay Over Cookies

abstract: Caucus column; Indiana Gov Mitch Daniels criticizes Mitt Romney in interview day after endorsing him for president. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: After an Endorsement, Some Pointed Advice

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney is preparing for the general election; aids say his staff of 87 will balloon to more than 400 people in the coming weeks, and his convention team of 44 will nearly triple to 150 by the time the event takes place in August. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney's Tight Ship Prepares to Take On More Hands for the Fall Campaign

abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds a rising number of Americans see improvement in the economy, but a persistent wariness about their own financial circumstances is allowing presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney to persuade voters that he could improve their economic prospects more than Pres Obama; poll finds the two men are locked in a tight race, with each gathering 46 percent of the support. Photos, Graphs (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and ALLISON KOPICKI; Dalia Sussman and Marina Stefan contributed reporting
headline: Economic Doubts Offer an Opening to Romney Camp

abstract: Caucus column; Democrats seize on vaguely threatening remarks that rock star Ted Nugent made at a National Rifle Assn conference; Obama and Romney camps issue statements saying there is no place in the campaign for such comments; Nugent has endorsed Romney. Photo (M)i
author: DAVE ITZKOFF
headline: Star Power: A Romney Fan Gets Some Room

abstract: Mitt Romney's position on the Afghanistan war is likely to come under more scrutiny now that he has emerged as the likely Republican presidential nominee; Romney has loosely embraced the main thrust of the Obama administration's war policy, despite offering a tough critique of Pres Obama's handling of the war. Photo (M)a
author: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
headline: Romney Critique of War Policy Gets Closer Look

abstract: Mitt Romney selects Beth Myers, a long-time adviser, to supervise his search for a running mate; her attention to detail and willingness to challenge him, honed in a series of supporting roles throughout his political ascent, underpinned his decision to trust her with this responsibility. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER; Michael Barbaro reported from Pittsburgh, and Ashley Parker from Boston
headline: Romney Aide Turns Focus To the Search For His No. 2

abstract: Senior advisers to Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, say that he was merely tossing around ideas, not making policy announcements, when his chat with donors about significant changes to the tax code was overheard by reporters at a fund-raiser. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting
headline: Aides Play Down Romney's Talk on Taxes for Wealthy

abstract: New joint fund-raising initiative between presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney and the Republican National Committee will aim to raise $800 million by November; the initiative is part of what Romney's campaign estimates will be a total of $1 billion spent to defeat Pres Obama. (M)
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: Romney Backers Set a Goal To Raise $800 Million by Fall

abstract: Caucus column; Rep Ron Paul and Newt Gingrich are continuing their primary campaigns despite near universal consensus that Mitt Romney will be the Republican nominee for president; both candidates are defying calls to rally around Romney, insisting that their ongoing efforts will allow them to influence debate all the way to Republican National Convention. (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Gingrich and Paul Defy Calls to Rally Around Romney

abstract: Mitt Romney and House Republicans diverge on some legislative issues, and Republican lawmakers have said that they will tolerate differences on more minor issues as long as Romney understands that they are driving the party's policy agenda; Romney's campaign has set up meetings with House members in order to ensure that the party acts in lock-step to defeat Pres Obama. Photos (M)
author: JONATHAN WEISMAN and JENNIFER STEINHAUER
headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers And Romney Face A Delicate Tango

abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F Geithner forcefully rejects Mitt Romney's campaign assertion that unemployment has affected more women than men during the Obama administration. (M)
author: BRIAN KNOWLTON
headline: Geithner Scolds Romney Over Women and Jobs

abstract: Screenwriter Etan Cohen imagines a screenplay dialogue between Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney in which Gingrich is the Republican presidential candidate and Romney is the vice-presidential candidate.
author: ETAN COHEN
headline: How Might Gingrich Coax Romney to Concede?

abstract: Screenwriter Etan Cohen imagines a screenplay dialogue between Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney in which Gingrich is the Republican presidential candidate and Romney is the vice-presidential candidate. Drawings (M)
author: ETAN COHEN
headline: Newt's Big Idea

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney speaks to the National Rifle Assn, seeking support of a powerful group that has not always warmed up to him; appears at NRA's annual gathering just as the group's powerful grip on gun legislation has come under renewed scrutiny due to permissive defense laws it has promoted. Photos (M)1
author: TRIP GABRIEL; Steven Yaccino contributed reporting
headline: Romney Assures Gun Rights Group of His Fealty

abstract: Caucus column; Newt Gingrich becomes the latest presidential candidate to lash out at Fox News, accusing the channel of dooming his flagging campaign by slanting its political coverage to benefit Mitt Romney. Photo (M)2
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Accusations: Gingrich Blasts Fox News, And Fox News Blasts Back

abstract: Evangelical leaders have begun to cautiously embrace Mitt Romney, now that Rick Santorum, who enjoyed their strong support, has suspended his campaign; some leaders have noted that their shared hostility toward Pres Obama will be a powerful force for uniting the party, and overcoming their previous criticisms of Romney.
author: ERIK ECKHOLM
headline: Santorum Out, Evangelicals Edge Closer to Romney, but Warily

abstract: Massachusetts Democratic Party will hold a birthday celebration for the state's landmark health care law, which was signed by then-Gov Mitt Romney six years ago; leaders call for Romney to be proud of his accomplishment, which has been a serious political liability during his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination. Photos (M)2
author: ABBY GOODNOUGH
headline: Celebrating Health Law, With a Poke At Romney

abstract: Mitt Romney's Republican presidential campaign finds itself squeezed between its intensifying efforts to appeal to women and its need to avoid alienating conservatives; Washington Post/ABC News poll shows that women prefer Pres Obama to Romney by 19 percentage points, and Gallup/USA Today poll of voters in 12 key swing states shows Obama leading overall, buoyed by independents and women, two critical voting blocs. Photo, Graphs (M)a
author: ASHLEY PARKER and TRIP GABRIEL; Reporting was contributed by Nicholas Confessore, Alison Kopicki, Michael D. Shear, and Catherine Rampell
headline: Romney Taking Steps to Narrow His Gender Gap

abstract: Evangelical leaders have begun to cautiously embrace Mitt Romney, now that Rick Santorum, who enjoyed their strong support, has suspended his campaign; some leaders have noted that their shared hostility toward Pres Obama will be a powerful force for uniting the party, and overcoming their previous criticisms of Romney. Photo (M)
author: ERIK ECKHOLM
headline: Santorum Out, Evangelicals Edge Closer to Romney, but Warily

abstract: "Rick Santorum announces that he is ending his presidential campaign, clearing the way for Mitt Romney to claim the Republican nomination;" Santorum's exit dashes the hopes of social conservatives, who had propelled his surprisingly successful challenge to the Republican establishment.
author: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and JIM RUTENBERG
headline: Santorum Quits Race, Clearing a Path for Romney

abstract: Rick Santorum announces that he is ending his presidential campaign, clearing the way for Mitt Romney to claim the Republican nomination; Santorum's exit dashes the hopes of social conservatives, who had propelled his surprisingly successful challenge to the Republican establishment. Map, Photos, Charts (M)
author: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and JIM RUTENBERG; Katharine Q. Seelye reported from Gettysburg, Pa., and Jim Rutenberg from New York. Trip Gabriel contributed reporting from Wilmington, Del., Jeff Zeleny from Washington and Ashley Parker from New York
headline: Santorum Quits Race, Clearing a Path for Romney

abstract: Two-and-a-half minute video leaked to Web site Gawker shows Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney making small talk before interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity in Las Vegas; conversation reveals a thrifty side of Romney, who said he would rather spend money on ads than a pricey hotel room. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Not Everything Stays in Vegas

abstract: Romney campaign pulls ads critical of Republican presidential rival Rick Santorum in Pennsylvania after Santorums three-year-old disabled daughter, Bella, is hospitalized; her medical struggles--and the public outpouring of sympathy for her--have the potential to complicate Romney's efforts to quickly end the Republican nominating fight.
author: TRIP GABRIEL and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
headline: A Shift in Strategy in Pennsylvania for Romney

abstract: Romney campaign pulls ads critical of Republican presidential rival Rick Santorum in Pennsylvania after Santorum's three-year-old disabled daughter, Bella, is hospitalized; her medical struggles--and the public outpouring of sympathy for her--have the potential to complicate Romney's efforts to quickly end the Republican nominating fight. Photos (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE; Trip Gabriel reported from New York, and Katharine Q. Seelye from Bedford, Pa
headline: A Shift in Strategy in Pennsylvania for Romney

abstract: The friendship between Mitt Romney and Benjamin Netanyahu, little known to outsiders, is now rich with political intrigue.
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: A Friendship Dating to 1976 Resonates in 2012

abstract: Garrett Jackson is Republican presidential contender Mitt Romney's so-called 'body man,' the personal assistant who spends more time with the candidate than even Romney's wife Ann; Jackson has begun blogging about his days with Romney, an acknowledgement that it might help voters connect to a candidate who has been called out of touch. Photos (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Starting the Day, and Ending It, at Romney's Side

abstract: Mitt Romney is firmly in the lead there, but under the state Republican Partys new rules, the winner no longer takes all.
author: THOMAS KAPLAN
headline: Delegates Up for Grabs In Primary in New York

abstract: New York Republican leaders are anticipating a competitive presidential primary race, because the state party has replaced its winner-take-all primary with a more complex system that could allow other candidates to pick up delegates, even if Mitt Romney wins the most votes, as expected. (M)
author: THOMAS KAPLAN
headline: Delegates Up for Grabs In Primary in New York

abstract: Rick Santorum has not yet acknowledged defeat in the face of Mitt Romney's three-state primary sweep, but his advisers admit that the path to victory has now become obscure; his future has been cast in doubt not only by a widening delegate gap, but increasing signs that his conservative base may be turning away.
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Santorum Sees Long Campaign Road Ahead, but Many See Dead End

abstract: Rick Santorum has said he must and will win his home state of Pennsylvania, but now he and Mitt Romney are trying to manage expectations.
author: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
headline: Santorum's Fight to Stay Relevant

abstract: Political Memo; 2012 presidential campaign, marked by mercurial public enthusiasm for a host of different candidates, is unlikely to stabilize now that Republicans have begun rallying around Mitt Romney; will likely remain narrowly contested, revolving around the mobilization of party loyalists and an attempt to win over a small slice of voters who will remain undecided until almost the end. (M)
author: JOHN HARWOOD
headline: After a Rollicking Primary, a Different Kind of Fight in November

abstract: Rick Santorum has not yet acknowledged defeat in the face of Mitt Romney's three-state primary sweep, but his advisers admit that the path to victory has now become obscure; his future has been cast in doubt not only by a widening delegate gap, but increasing signs that his conservative base may be turning away. Photo (M)0
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Santorum Sees Long Campaign Road Ahead, but Many See Dead End

abstract: Both Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney and Pres Obama are seizing on the Republican House budget, and its ambitious young architect, Rep Paul D Ryan, as a defining issue of the unfolding campaign; Romney tightens his embrace of Ryan despite a withering assault from Obama on the Ryan spending plan and what he said it reflects about Republican priorities. Photos (M)
author: MARK LANDLER; Ashley Parker contributed reporting from Philadelphia
headline: Budget Author, a Romney Ally, Turns Into a Campaign Focus

abstract: Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romneys campaign is hoping for momentum heading into Pennsylvania, the home state of rival Rick Santorum, who has called it a must-win primary; even without a victory, Romney's aides think he can win more than half of its 72 delegates.
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Pennsylvania Lets Romney Go Straight for Jugular

abstract: Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney's campaign is hoping for momentum heading into Pennsylvania, the home state of rival Rick Santorum, who has called it a must-win primary; even without a victory, Romney's aides think he can win more than half of its 72 delegates. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Pennsylvania Lets Romney Go Straight For Jugular

abstract: Fairly moderate electorate in Wisconsin provides a particular window into swing state characteristics that are being intensely studied by both parties; exit polls show that more than 8 in 10 Wisconsin Republican primary voters say they think Mitt Romney will be the party's standard-bearer. Chart, Photos (M)l
author: ALLISON KOPICKI
headline: In Wisconsin Exit Polls, Hints at the Leanings of November Voters

abstract: Polls in the past week have shown Mitt Romney, who trailed Rick Santorum in mid-February, solidifying a lead in Wisconsin.
author: TRIP GABRIEL; Ashley Parker contributed reporting
headline: Wisconsin Votes After Fiercely Fought Battle

abstract: Political Memo; despite the delegate gap, Rick Santorum is digging in for another month of hard campaigning, seeking to capture the Republican presidential nomination as long as he can see a path to win, even if it means forcing an open convention; launches new negative ad campaign attacking Mitt Romney as a moderate.
author: JIM RUTENBERG and TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Weighing When Slim Hopes Become G.O.P. Problem

abstract: Text and assessment of Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum's campaign advertisement that aired in Wisconsin, which makes several misleading claims about Mitt Romney's record as governor of Massachusetts. Photo (M)a
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Ad Watch: Santorum Keeps Heat on Romney

abstract: Political Memo; despite the delegate gap, Rick Santorum is digging in for another month of hard campaigning, seeking to capture the Republican presidential nomination as long as he can see a path to win, even if it means forcing an open convention; launches new negative ad campaign attacking Mitt Romney as a moderate. Photo (M)2
author: JIM RUTENBERG and TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Weighing When Slim Hopes Become a G.O.P. Problem

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney responds to attack on his Mormon faith by a voter at town hall-style meeting in Wisconsin. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: A Question on Religion

abstract: Caucus column; character in episode of television drama Mad Men, which is set in the 1960s, mocks George Romney, Mitt's father who was governor of Michigan at that time in what could be a veiled political jab against the 2012 Republican presidential front-runner. Photos (M)
author: DAVE ITZKOFF
headline: On The Screen: Some See Veiled 2012 Political Jab, Circa 1966

abstract: Rick Santorum, trailing Mitt Romney at the polls and in terms of endorsements, has made four appearances at bowling alleys across Wisconsin in an effort to drive home his working-class credentials.
author: TRIP GABRIEL and NICK CORASANITI
headline: For Santorum, Hope That Voters See Message as Pins Go Flying

abstract: Rick Santorum, trailing Mitt Romney at the polls and in terms of endorsements, has made four appearances at bowling alleys across Wisconsin in an effort to drive home his working-class credentials. Photo (M)l
author: TRIP GABRIEL and NICK CORASANITI; Trip Gabriel reported from Chilton, Wis., and Nick Corasaniti from New York. Katharine Q. Seelye contributed reporting from New York
headline: For Santorum, Hope That Voters Will See a Message as the Pins Go Flying

abstract: Mitt Romney's campaign will release two of its Wisconsin television advertisements online, in the hopes of reaching the growing number of voters who watch television through Web browsers or DVRs; move signals a potential shift in the economics of political advertising, as tracking technology allows candidates to target blocs of viewers who are most likely to sympathize with their views. Photos (M)
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: As TV Viewing Habits Change, Political Ads Follow Would-Be Voters Online

abstract: Campaign Memo profiles Charlie Black, a prototypical informal adviser and familiar Washington campaign lifer who is among those counseling Mitt Romney.; Black is available for old-pro advice, back-channel information and whatever else the campaign happens to need. Photos (M)
author: MARK LEIBOVICH; Kitty Bennett contributed research
headline: Aides With a Candidate's Ear, If Not Any Titles or Paychecks

abstract: Wisconsin polls show Mitt Romney leading Rick Santorum in Republican presidential primary; victory would neutralize his most powerful critics and rally a broad spectrum of conservatives behind him as party leaders grow increasingly eager to take on Pres Obama. Photos (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG; Jeremy W. Peters contributed reporting from Waukesha, Wis
headline: In Wisconsin, Romney Nears the Tipping Point

abstract: Mitt Romney's remarks on cultural differences between Israelis and Palestinians during his high-profile overseas trip draws a pointed rebuke from the Palestinian leadership; controversy comes just days after Romney drew pointed barbs from British leaders by questioning the London's preparedness and enthusiasm for the Olympics. Photos (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.; Ashley Parker reported from Jerusalem, and Richard A. Oppel Jr. from New York
headline: Romney Trip Raises Sparks At a 2nd Stop

abstract: A breakfast in Jerusalem on Monday for nearly four dozen high-dollar donors was expected to raise just over $1 million for Mitt Romneys campaign.
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Courts Campaign Donors in Israel

abstract: Henry Alford travel article explores the lakefront town of Wolfeboro, NH, where Mitt Romney vacations, to see what it can tell him about the presidential candidate.
author: HENRY ALFORD
headline: Vacationing Like a Candidate

abstract: Campaign of presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney decides that his high-dollar breakfast with donors in Jerusalem will be closed to the news media, a change from the norm for him; trip to Israel holds both opportunity and peril for Romney. (M)l
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Fund-Raiser For Romney In Israel Bars Media

abstract: Mitt Romney adopted the language of Israels leaders, who say Tehran must not even obtain the capability to build a nuclear weapon, a harder position than the United States has taken.
author: JODI RUDOREN and ASHLEY PARKER; David E. Sanger contributed reporting from Dallas
headline: Romney Backs Israeli Position On Facing Iran

abstract: Mitt Romney's visit to Israel is a critical opportunity to showcase his statesmanship, particularly after his rocky overseas debut in Great Britain, and to highlight his relationship with Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu. Photo (M)/
author: JODI RUDOREN and ASHLEY PARKER; Jodi Rudoren reported from Jerusalem, and Ashley Parker from London. Jo Craven McGinty contributed reporting from New York
headline: Romney Faces Perils and Opportunities in Israel

abstract: Mitt Romney's visit to Israel is a critical opportunity to showcase his statesmanship, particularly after his rocky overseas debut in Great Britain, and to highlight his relationship with Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu. Photo (M)/
author: JODI RUDOREN and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Faces Perils and Opportunities in Israel

abstract: A trip to the lakefront town of Wolfeboro, N.H., to see what its like where Mitt Romney unwinds.
author: HENRY ALFORD
headline: Vacationing Like A Candidate

abstract: Mitt Romney finds a supportive audience at London fund-raisers heavily populated with American financiers, due to his ties to the industry and his tax-cutting promises; Romney's remarks steer clear of the Libor scandal over interest rates, which has set of a vocal anti-banker backlash in the city. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER and LANDON THOMAS Jr
headline: Romney Fund-Raisers in London Draw Banking Crowd

abstract: Mitt Romney's visit to London causes a diplomatic stir when he expresses concerns about Olympics planning, security and support, prompting a rebuff by Prime Minister David Cameron and attention from the news media; Romney's comments come on the first day of a highly anticipated trip expected to test his skills in foreign diplomacy, terrain on which he is not as comfortable as he is on economic issues. Photos (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER; Helene Cooper contributed reporting from Washington
headline: A Visitor's Questions on Readiness for Games Prompt a Curt Response

abstract: Caucus column; Union Leader, a newspaper in Manchester, NH, known for its conservative editorial stances, slams Mitt Romney for not releasing several years of his tax returns. (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: A Conservative Critic: Paper Pushes for Tax Returns

abstract: Political Memo; furor surrounding Mitt Romney's remark questioning Britain's preparedness of the London Olympics offers the latest example of how his campaign often finds itself scrambling for damage control rather than controlling the script. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: For Romney, an Olympic Stage Less Welcoming Than the One in 2002

abstract: Amid a rate-rigging scandal, Mitt Romney found support with financiers in London because of his ties to the industry and his tax-cutting promises.
author: ASHLEY PARKER and LANDON THOMAS Jr
headline: Romney Fund-Raisers in London Draw Banking Crowd

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney's most prominent Jewish supporters, including billionaire Sheldon Adelson, will be on hand during the candidate's trip to Israel. Photo (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY
headline: Top Donors Will Travel To Israel for Romney Visit

abstract: Mitt Romney opens a new and aggressive attack against Pres Obama on national security on the eve of an overseas trip intended to burnish his foreign policy credentials; in an address at the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in Reno, Nev, Romney accuses the Obama administration of leaking national security secrets for political gain and failing to stand up to adversaries like China, Russia and Iran. Photo (M)
author: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.; Helene Cooper contributed reporting from Portland, Ore
headline: Romney Blasts Security Leaks As a Betrayal

abstract: Pres Obama directs a sharp assault on Mitt Romney's foreign policy credentials, arguing that Romney is too willing to go to war, as both candidates resume campaigning after a weekend political truce that followed the shooting rampage in Colorado. Photo (M)y
author: HELENE COOPER and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.; Richard A. Oppel Jr. contributed reporting from Costa Mesa, Calif
headline: President Criticizes Romney Over Foreign Policy

abstract: Brian McFadden The Strip comic offers speculations about Mitt Romney's finances. Cartoon (S)
author: BRIAN McFADDEN
headline: The Strip

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney's fundraising trip to England, Israel and Poland comes with potential risks and rewards, allowing him to compete with the international stature of the sitting president but opening him to criticisms concerning his foreign policy. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: A Week Abroad, With Pitfalls and Payoffs

abstract: Mitt Romney will embark on a trip to Britain, Israel and Poland to try to establish a solid foreign policy doctrine that distinguishes him from Pres Obama. Photos (M)
author: HELENE COOPER and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
headline: Overseas, Romney Will Try to Hone Foreign Policy

abstract: Michael O Leavitt, one of presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's top aides, has spent two years advising states and private insurers on how to comply with the health care law, but his work has caused consternation among some conservatives, who want states to resist the Affordable Care Act. Photos (M)/
author: ROBERT PEAR
headline: Romney Aide Advises On State Health Plans

abstract: Two London fund-raising events have become a public relations headache for Mitt Romney, as several of the events' hosts are top executives at banks tied to the city's widening interest rate-fixing scandal. Photo (M)p
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE; Sarah Wheaton contributed reporting
headline: London Fund-Raisers Put Romney in a Scandal's Glare

abstract: Caucus column; YouTube advertisement by presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney is taken down due to a copyright claim by BMG Rights Management; ad mocked Pres Obama's rendition of Al Green's 1972 hit Let's Stay Together. (M)d
author: NICK CORASANITI
headline: Music Company Short-Circuits Romney Ad

abstract: Mitt Romney remains steadfast in his refusal to release any of his tax returns from before 2010, despite millions of dollars in searing ads from Pres Obama and a rising chorus of frustrated Republicans. Photo (M)l
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and TRIP GABRIEL; Michael D. Shear reported from New York, and Trip Gabriel from Bowling Green, Ohio
headline: Romney Steadfast in the Face of Growing Calls to Release More Tax Returns

abstract: Text and assessment of television ad released by Mitt Romney's presidential campaign that contends stimulus money went to Pres Obama's political donors and to overseas companies. Photo (M)
author: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
headline: A Romney Attack on Spending

abstract: Republicans close to Mitt Romney's presidential campaign say that they fear New Jersey Gov Chris Christie is too unpredictable and too contentious, and as a result his potential as a vice-presidential pick is fading; if Christie is not chosen, it would inevitably raise questions about his future in national politics. Photo (M)
author: KATE ZERNIKE; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from New York
headline: Christie's Brashness Blunts Hopes to Join Ticket

abstract: Aides to presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney are thoroughly vetting possible vice presidential picks,cloaking the process in secrecy; possible running mates, who have handed over reams of documents to the campaign, may have opened themselves to a greater level of scrutiny than Romney himself; search is designed to avoid the kind of rushed and risky choice of Sarah Palin that bedeviled Sen John McCain in 2008. Photos (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER and MICHAEL BARBARO; Jeff Zeleny contributed reporting from Washington
headline: Seeking No. 2., Romney Campaign Puts Caution Over Flash

abstract: Campaign advisers to presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney hint that he may defy custom and disclose his vice-presidential pick well ahead of the Republican convention; say with polls showing a close race, a warmly received running mate could significantly energize Romney's candidacy. (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: After the Who, The Question Of the When

abstract: Descendants of Mormons who made the great trek to Utah in the 1840s have turned out in strength to back Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, whose great-grandfather Miles Romney settled alongside many of their ancestors in Nauvoo in 1841; records show that roughly two dozen members of Mormon families provided nearly $8 million of the financing for the Romney super PAC, Restore Our Future, putting them in league with its Wall Street, real estate and energy donors. Photos (M)
author: JIM RUTENBERG; Lisa Schwartz contributed research
headline: Mormons' First Families Rally Behind Romney

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney's campaign tells reporters that his decision on a vice-presidential candidate has not yet been finalized, despite reports to the contrary. (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: And for Vice President: Still Awaiting Decision

abstract: "Tim Pawlenty is being considered for the Republican ticket, after a short-lived presidential bid of his own;" one-time rival Mitt Romney, who is on the cusp of announcing his vice-presidential selection, has embraced Pawlenty, seeking his advice about running against President Obama and sending him to Republican events on his behalf. (Series: The Ticket)
author: JEFF ZELENY
headline: In Pawlenty, Romney Campaign May Find Down-to-Earth Appeal

abstract: Descendants of Mormons who made the great trek to Utah in the 1840s have turned out in strength to back Mitt Romney.
author: JIM RUTENBERG; Lisa Schwartz contributed research
headline: Mormons' First Families Rally Behind Romney
