abstract: Members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints find a spiritual oasis in an annual, 750-actor portrayal of the Book of Mormon at the faith's birthplace of Palmyra, NY; pageant has taken place for 75 years, but 2012 is the first year in which a Mormon, Mitt Romney, is the presumptive presidential nominee for a major party, and event has become a much-needed break from the current din of politics. Photos (M)
author: SHARON OTTERMAN
headline: Amid Pageantry, a Respite From Politics

abstract: Mitt Romney is facing a barrage of attacks over the question of his departure from Bain Capital, but the facts in the matter have proven difficult to explain in the simple terms favored by political discourse; complications arise in part from the ways in which Bain was organized, which left him technically in control of, and owner of, part of the company even when he was working on the Olympic Games. (M)/
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Michael Luo and Kitty Bennett contributed reporting
headline: When Did Romney Step Back From Bain? It's Complicated, Filings Suggest

abstract: Caucus column; report that Condoleezza Rice is considered as the front-runner to be Mitt Romney's vice-presidential nominee is called into question by conservatives, who cite several reasons why she would be an unlikely pick. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: A Trial Balloon Loses Some Air

abstract: Mitt Romney, speaking before the NAACP, delivers a tough critique of Pres Obama and attempts to make the case that he represents the better choice for blacks; Romney's assertions are met with a mix of cackles, boos and tepid applause.
author: ASHLEY PARKER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Romney Says He Offers Better Chance for Blacks

abstract: Obama campaign seizes on a Boston Globe report about Securities and Exchange Commission documents showing that Mitt Romney was listed as the chief executive, president and owner of Bain Capital from 1999 to 2002, contradicting Romney's assertion that he left the firm in 1999; finding shores up Obama campaign's argument that Romney was still at Bain's helm when some of its companies moved workers overseas; definitive proof of Romney's activities remains elusive, leading to another day of bitter charges and countercharges from the two campaigns. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Campaigns Trade Salvos Over a Romney Role at Bain After 1999

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney will speak to the NAACP, hoping his pro-jobs message will persuade some African-American voters; while blacks are expected to solidly back Pres Obama again in the election, he faces challenges in generating the same enthusiasm as in 2008.
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Romney Makes a Push for Black Voters

abstract: Mitt Romney, speaking before the NAACP, delivers a tough critique of Pres Obama and attempts to make the case that he represents the better choice for blacks; Romney's assertions are met with a mix of cackles, boos and tepid applause. Photo (M)d
author: ASHLEY PARKER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Ashley Parker reported from Houston, and Michael D. Shear from Washington
headline: Romney Says He Offers Better Chance for Blacks

abstract: Campaign memo; Mitt Romney and his advisers were aggressive and tough during the Republican primaries, but his recent restraint has opened a round of second-guessing about his insistent focus on the economy as Democrats have turned attention to other topics; some Republicans worry he is not nimble and aggressive enough to withstand the Democratic assault against him. Photo (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and ASHLEY PARKER; Jeff Zeleny reported from Washington, and Ashley Parker from Houston
headline: Romney Faces Calls to Deliver Counterpunch

abstract: Caucus column; George P Bush, the eldest son of former Florida Gov Jeb Bush, says it is never too late for presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney to take a leadership role in the immigration debate. Photo (M)d
author: JEFF ZELENY
headline: The Immigration Debate: A Bush Tells Romney 'It's Never Too Late' to Lead

abstract: Mitt Romneys participation in a tiny law-and-business dual-degree graduate program at Harvard University, which has graduated a striking number of big names in finance, industry, law and government since it began in 1969, puts him into one of the most exclusive clubs in academe.
author: PETER LATTMAN and RICHARD PREZ-PEA
headline: Romney, at Harvard, Merged Two Worlds

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney will speak to the NAACP, hoping his pro-jobs message will persuade some African-American voters; while blacks are expected to solidly back Pres Obama again in the election, he faces challenges in generating the same enthusiasm as in 2008. (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Romney Makes a Push for Black Voters

abstract: Mitt Romney's participation in a tiny law-and-business dual-degree graduate program at Harvard University, which has graduated a striking number of big names in finance, industry, law and government since it began in 1969, puts him into one of the most exclusive clubs in academe. Photos (M)
author: PETER LATTMAN and RICHARD PREZ-PEA
headline: Romney, at Harvard, Merged Two Worlds

abstract: Mitt Romney's participation in a tiny law-and-business dual-degree graduate program at Harvard University, which has graduated a striking number of big names in finance, industry, law and government since it began in 1969, puts him into one of the most exclusive clubs in academe. Photos (M)
author: PETER LATTMAN and RICHARD PREZ-PEA
headline: Romney, at Harvard, Merged Two Worlds

abstract: Mitt Romney's participation in a tiny law-and-business dual-degree graduate program at Harvard University, which has graduated a striking number of big names in finance, industry, law and government since it began in 1969, puts him into one of the most exclusive clubs in academe. Photos (M)
author: PETER LATTMAN and RICHARD PREZ-PEA
headline: Romney, at Harvard, Merged Two Worlds

abstract: MItt Romney attends three major fund-raisers in East Hampton, New York, where he is expected to haul in close to $4 million; day of elegant parties is disrupted by protests from groups who say they are offended by the reach of corporate money in Republican politics. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and SARAH WHEATON; Michael Barbaro reported from East Hampton, and Sarah Wheaton from Southampton, N.Y. Jim Rutenberg contributed reporting from Montauk, N.Y
headline: Romney Mines the Hamptons for Campaign Cash

abstract: "Blistering editorial in Rupert Murdoch's flagship Wall Street Journal criticizing Mitt Romney is a stern reminder of Romneys failure to win the trust of the Republican Partys core conservatives, a group that pays close attention to Murdochs newspapers and cable news outlets;" Murdochs dim view of Romney points to a palpable disconnect between the two men, one that has existed since Romneys first run for president in 2008.
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Shots by Murdoch at Romney Play Out to Conservative Core

abstract: Mitt Romney is asking voters to condemn Pres Obama for a health insurance mandate that is nearly identical to the one he championed as the governor of Massachusetts; Romney has allied himself with the rest of the Republican Party in labeling Obama's mandate a tax, in effect asking voters to ignore his own record. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and ASHLEY PARKER; Reporting was contributed by John H. Cushman Jr. and Adam Liptak from Washington, Michael Barbaro from New York and Kitty Bennett from Florida
headline: In Defending His Health Care Plan, Romney Often Called Its Mandate a Tax

abstract: Blistering editorial in Rupert Murdoch's flagship Wall Street Journal criticizing Mitt Romney is a stern reminder of Romney's failure to win the trust of the Republican Party's core conservatives, a group that pays close attention to Murdoch's newspapers and cable news outlets; Murdoch's dim view of Romney points to a palpable disconnect between the two men, one that has existed since Romney's first run for president in 2008. Photos (M)
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Shots by Murdoch at Romney Play Out to Conservative Core

abstract: Rep Bob Turner says that he plans to campaign for Wendy E Long in race for Sen Kirsten E Gillibrand's seat, and for presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney; says he does not imagine running for office again.
author: THOMAS KAPLAN
headline: Its Back to Retirement for a New Congressman

abstract: "Sen Rob Portman of Ohio is widely believed to be a top pick for Mitt Romney's running mate;" has ascended the ranks from staff member to senator over three decades and is admired by Romney for his keen and deep understanding of the inner workings of government (Series: The Ticket).
author: JEFF ZELENY
headline: Possible No. 2 to Romney Knows Ways of the Capital

abstract: Rep Bob Turner says that he plans to campaign for Wendy E Long in race for Sen Kirsten E Gillibrand's seat, and for presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney; says he does not imagine running for office again. Photo, Map (M)7
author: THOMAS KAPLAN
headline: For New Congressman, It's Back to Retirement

abstract: Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, will visit Israel this summer to meet with Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Salam Fayyad, the prime minister of the Palestinian Authority; trip is an opportunity to appeal both to Jewish voters and donors, whose support of Pres Obama appears to have lessened, and to evangelical Christians, whose trust he is still fighting to win. Photos (M)
author: JODI RUDOREN
headline: Romney, an Eye on Campaign, Plans a Trip to Israel

abstract: Mitt Romney's presidential campaign contradicts a central Republican attack line by saying President Obama's health care mandate would be a penalty, not a tax; in straying from the party message, Romney's campaign offers fresh example of his difficulty in promoting the conservative approach toward health care because he had previously championed universal health coverage while governor of Massachusetts. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Romney Campaign and G.O.P. at Odds on Health Care 'Tax'

abstract: Mitt Romney's trip to his summer home in Wolfeboro, New Hampshire, attracts the usual corps of reporters and media followers, giving the quiet town a foretaste of the disruption it can expect should Romney become president. Photos (M)m
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: For a Vacation Spot, It's Not Just Another Summer

abstract: Anonymous donor pays FC New York, a minor league soccer club on Long Island, to place the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney's name and campaign slogan, Believe in America, on the front of the team's jerseys. (S)
author: JACK BELL
headline: Sports Briefing | Soccer

abstract: Mitt Romney faces increased pressure to flesh out alternatives to the health care reform law, which the Supreme Court has upheld and which he and Republicans have professed to despise. Photo (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL and ROBERT PEAR
headline: Parsing Romney's Choices on Health Care

abstract: Sharp differences emerged among Mitt Romneys advisers as they weighed a response to the Obama administrations handling of the case of a Chinese dissident.
author: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
headline: Diplomatic Crisis Gives Romney Campaign a Chance to Work Out Its Policy

abstract: Caucus column; comment made by Mike Turzai, Pennsylvania's House majority leader, that the state's new voter ID law would help Mitt Romney win the state reignites a debate over whether the law is intended to curb fraud, as Republicans claim, or to depress Democratic turnout, as Democrats charge. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL COOPER
headline: Pennsylvania's Voter ID Law Spurs Debate

abstract: Three-day retreat in Park City, Utah, for Mitt Romney's biggest campaign contributors offered an extraordinary level of access to the candidate and his staff; retreat, attended by many of the Republican party's biggest stars, is symbolic of both Romney's fundraising prowess and the party's consolidated support for his candidacy. (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO; Jim Rutenberg contributed reporting from New York
headline: For Wealthy Romney Donors, Up Close and Personal Access

abstract: Caucus column; Politico, Web site devoted to covering all facets of the political news cycle, announces that it has suspended Joe Williams, a White House reporter, for making numerous disparaging and vulgar comments about Mitt Romney. (M)
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Politico Suspends Reporter

abstract: Bain Capital, the private equity firm co-founded by Mitt Romney, structured its deals so that it was hard for the firm and its executives to ever really lose, even if practically everyone else involved with a company that Bain owned did, including its employees, creditors and even, at times, investors in Bain's funds; Bain officials vigorously dispute any notion that the firm profited when its investors lost, arguing that a full accounting of their costs across their business would show otherwise. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL LUO and JULIE CRESWELL; Mike McIntire contributed reporting
headline: Fees Flowed to Romney's Firm As Companies It Owned Failed

abstract: Caucus column; Jim Wilson, outspoken supporter of Mitt Romney, reports that his truck was destroyed by fire on Interstate 70 in Pennsylvania; truck had been festooned in pro-Romney slogans. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Campaign Casualty: Pro-Romney Truck Destroyed

abstract: Mitt Romney struck a more conciliatory tone toward illegal immigrants than he has in the past, but backed only limited steps to address the concerns of many Hispanic voters.
author: ASHLEY PARKER and TRIP GABRIEL; Ashley Parker reported from Lake Buena Vista, and Trip Gabriel from New York
headline: Romney Exhibits A Change In Tone On Immigration

abstract: Donors and fund-raisers who have contributed $50,000 or raised $250,000 for Mitt Romney's campaign will gather for a two-day event in Utah; Romney's fund-raising success has hinged on his clout in the business world and his relentless personal cultivation of contributors. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Romney's Personal Touch Pays Off With Donors

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney campaigns in DeWitt, Mich; he believes Michigan is up for grabs in the election and his campaign plans to force Pres Obama and the Democrats to spend resources in the state that they would prefer to deploy elsewhere; Obama carried the state in the 2008 election. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Suddenly, Michigan Looks Like More Fertile Ground to Romney Campaign

abstract: Mitt Romney has used a string of recent campaign stops as an informal audition for prospective running mates; prominent contenders include Sen Rob Portman of Ohio and Rep Paul D Ryan Jr of Wisconsin.
author: JEFF ZELENY and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: On and Off the Romney Bus, Tryouts for a Spot on the Ticket

abstract: Mitt Romney, who often struggles with small talk on the trail, campaigned through six swing states during a five-day bus tour.
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Road Trip Helps Romney Brush Up on Banter

abstract: Mitt Romney, in television appearance, remains equivocal about Pres Obama's decision to halt deportations of many illegal immigrants, moderating his previously tough stance on immigration issues; accuses Obama of acting for purely political reasons. Photo (M)a
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: On TV, Romney Doesn't Show Immigration Hand

abstract: Jan Ebeling, Ann Romney's longtime riding tutor, and his horse Rafalca, earn a berth on the United States Olympic dressage team at the Olympic Games in London; Romney is co-owner of the horse.
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Romney Horse Wins Spot on Olympic Dressage Team

abstract: Mitt Romney has used a string of recent campaign stops as an informal audition for prospective running mates; prominent contenders include Sen Rob Portman of Ohio and Rep Paul D Ryan Jr of Wisconsin. Photos (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: On and Off Bus, Tryouts for No. 2 on Ticket

abstract: Ann Romneys longtime riding tutor, and his horse Rafalca, earned a berth on the United States Olympic dressage team on Saturday.
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Romney Horse Wins Spot on Olympic Dressage Team

abstract: Caucus column; Sen John McCain suggests in an interview that Restore Our Future, a super PAC backing presumptive Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, may have provided a conduit for foreign money to enter the presidential race. Photo (M)4
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: Seeing Door for Foreign Cash in Election

abstract: Mitt Romney is forced to wade gingerly into the debate about the new White House policy governing the deportation of young illegal immigrants as he kicks off a five-day bus tour of small-town America. Photo (M).
author: SARAH WHEATON
headline: Romney's Bus Tour of New Hampshire Lets In a Bit of the Outside World

abstract: Ann Romney has become much more visible on the stump in support of her husband, Mitt Romney, now that he has clinched the Republican presidential nomination.
author: ASHLEY PARKER; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from New York
headline: At Romney's Side, a Determined Running Mate

abstract: Ann Romney, who has been spotted wearing surprisingly stylish outfits while campaigning for her husband Mitt, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, appears willing to use fashion to counter his own buttoned-up image. Photos (M)
author: RUTH LA FERLA
headline: Writing Her Own Dress Code

abstract: Wealthy donors and corporations, in the wake of deregulation of the campaign finance system, are planning to pour hundreds of millions of dollars into the presidential and Congressional elections, mostly in support of Republicans; billionaire Sheldon Adelson has given at least $35 million to pro-Republican super PACS during the 2012 campaign, including a recent $10 million donation to presumptive GOP presidential nominee Mitt Romney. Photos, Chart (M)
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: Campaign Aid Is Now Surging Into 8 Figures

abstract: "Mitt Romney says that if elected president, he will seek to overhaul the federal government's largest school programs into a voucherlike system, replacing top-down Washington mandates;" students would be free to use $35 billion in federal money to attend any school they choose--public, charter, online or private--a system, he says, that would introduce marketplace dynamics into education to drive academic gains.
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Vouchers Unspoken, Romney Hails School Choice

abstract: Some of the nation's most influential evangelical groups urge a solution to illegal immigration that defies the harsh rhetoric of the Republican primary race, which continues to undermine presumptive GOP presidential nominee Mitt Romney's appeal to Hispanic voters. Photo (M)3
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Christians On Right Urge Reform On Migrants

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney will travel by bus to six swing states that voted Democratic in the 2008 presidential election but that his campaign believes can be battlegrounds in 2012. (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: By Bus, Romney To Visit Six States That Voted Blue

abstract: Mitt Romney says that if elected president, he will seek to overhaul the federal government's largest school programs into a voucherlike system, replacing top-down Washington mandates; students would be free to use $35 billion in federal money to attend any school they choose--public, charter, online or private--a system, he says, that would introduce marketplace dynamics into education to drive academic gains. Photos (M)/
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Vouchers Unspoken, Romney Hails School Choice

abstract: Caucus column; Texas Gov Rick Perry, addressing the state Republican Party convention, pokes fun at his gaffe-filled presidential campaign and throws his support behind one-time rival Mitt Romney. Photo (M)
author: MANNY FERNANDEZ
headline: In Texas, Perry Laughs At His White House Run

abstract: Residents of a wealthy coastal neighborhood of La Jolla, Calif, are rankled by both the politics and renovation plans of their neighbor Mitt Romney, who is seeking to quadruple the size of his waterfront home. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO; Roxana Popescue contributed reporting from San Diego
headline: The Candidate Next Door

abstract: Text and assessment of Pres Obama's campaign advertisement claiming that Mitt Romney was responsible for the loss of 40,000 manufacturing jobs when he was governor of Massachusetts; ad is scheduled to be broadcast in nine battleground states. (M)d
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Focus on State's Jobs in Romney Era

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney's choice of Michael O Leavitt as his transition chief spurs opposition from some conservatives over Leavitt's support of a crucial part of Pres Obama's health care plan. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Transition Chief: Conservatives Assail Romney Pick

abstract: White House and Congressional Democrats are making a push together to pass the Paycheck Fairness Act, a measure that makes it easier for women to sue over unequal pay; strategy shows how Democrats are attempting to mimic the way Republicans consistently coordinate their message with Mitt Romney's presidential campaign. Photo (M)y
author: JENNIFER STEINHAUER
headline: Democrats Grab a Chance To Speak With One Voice

abstract: Mitt Romney plans to double down on his strategy of pressing Pres Obama on economic issues, not letting focus stray from the struggles of average Americans; strategy is likely to prove even more effective in the wake of a weak jobs report. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: With Boos and Solyndra, Romney Plays Offense

abstract: Caucus column; personal financial disclosures filed by Mitt Romney's campaign show that he and his wife Ann have assets worth $83 million to $255 million. (M)0
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: Romneys Disclose Assets Of Up to $255 Million

abstract: In a sign that he is trying to attract more moderate general election voters, Mitt Romney is refining how he discusses taxes and health care.
author: MICHAEL COOPER
headline: Romney, Appealing to Wider Audience, Recalibrates Message

abstract: With President Obama consistently holding a lead in polls of Ohio, Mitt Romney may need to devise a strategy to win the Electoral College vote without it.
author: NATE SILVER
headline: Romneys Tough Path as He Trails in Ohio

abstract: Mitt Romney stepped up his efforts to repair the damage from his 47 percent comments, trying to reassure voters that he cares about the poor and middle class.
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Ad Reaches Out to Working Class

abstract: The Republican ticket will start campaigning together more often, which suggests that aides fear that Mitt Romney, on his own, is not generating enough attention and excitement.
author: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: A G.O.P. Reunion, With Plans for More Togetherness

abstract: Ralph Reed, who turned the Christian Coalition into a powerful political force, is planning a get-out-the-vote operation for Mitt Romney.
author: JO BECKER
headline: An Evangelical Is Back From Exile, Lifting Romney

abstract: Mitt Romneys remarks at fund-raisers highlight the differences, both subtle and significant, in how he talks to voters and donors, his two key constituencies.
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: With Rich Donors, a More Candid Romney Emerges

abstract: The candidate's controversial comment did not reflect the feelings of the very rich, but of the struggling middle class that is just above the 47 percent.
author: ANAND GIRIDHARADAS
headline: Romney Gaffe Reflects Real Sentiments

abstract: Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan are healthy and fit, according to medical summaries released on Friday by the Romney campaign.
author: LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN and DENISE GRADY
headline: G.O.P. Ticket Is Picture of Health, Doctors Say

abstract: David Twede, the editor of MormonThink, has encouraged Mormons to question church doctrine and has criticized Mitt Romney.
author: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
headline: Editor of Web Site May Face Mormon Excommunication

abstract: Mitt Romney responded to months of political pressure on Friday by making public his most recent tax return and limited information from previous years.
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI
headline: Romney Reveals He Paid 14% Rate in 2011 Tax Return

abstract: Federal election commission filings, along with disclosures by major super PACs, challenge the appearance of financial strength that had burnished Mitt Romney's campaign over the summer, and show unexpected strengths for Pres Obama going into the fall; much of what the Romney campaign reported sits in the accounts of the Republican National Committee, and only some of it will be available to Romney for his general election campaign.
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE, JO CRAVEN McGINTY and DEREK WILLIS
headline: Low on Cash, Romney Tries to Rally Donors for Final Phase

abstract: Political Memo; presidential campaign history overflows with examples of loose-tongued gaffes like the one Mitt Romney made at a secretly-recorded fundraiser.
author: JOHN HARWOOD
headline: Romney Is Latest in a Long Line to Trip Over a Tongue

abstract: There are 46 days left in this presidential race for Mitt Romney to change the dynamic of a campaign that by many indicators is tilting against him.
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG
headline: Before Debates, Romney Faces a Daunting Path

abstract: A left-leaning magazine is garnering attention with the release of a video showing Mitt Romney calling 47 percent of the public dependent on government and feeling like victims entitled to help.
author: CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY
headline: Video of Romney Turns Spotlight on a Magazine

abstract: Mitt Romney is intensifying his push for Hispanic voters, ratcheting up his Spanish-language advertising and putting himself in front of a growing number of Hispanic audiences.
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: On Air and Before Audiences, Romney Makes Push for Hispanic Vote

abstract: Mitt Romneys campaign has been tightfisted with its advertising budget, leaving him at a disadvantage in several crucial states as President Obama blankets them with ads.
author: JEREMY W. PETERS and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: Romney Campaign Cautious With Ad Budget, Even in Key States

abstract: A letter printed in a Church of St. Catherine of Siena bulletin endorsed Mitt Romney for president, prompting a complaint with the I.R.S. and a petition with more than 20,000 signatures.
author: JIM DWYER
headline: Priests Dip Into Politics Raises Outcry

abstract: Facing criticism for saying 47 percent of voters believe they are victims, Mitt Romney sought to steer the conversation toward a debate about governments role in peoples lives.
author: JIM RUTENBERG and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Says Remarks on Voters Help Clarify Position

abstract: Mitt Romneys views on the Middle East and Iran may have already been well known, but comments of his that were captured on video at a fund-raiser could bring difficulties if he wins the presidency.
author: DAVID E. SANGER
headline: Middle East Comments Could Vex a Romney Administration

abstract: Mitt Romneys campaign has pointed to a Republican resurgence in Wisconsin, but Mr. Romney trails by six points among likely voters, a new poll found.
author: JEFF ZELENY and MARJORIE CONNELLY
headline: Wisconsin Offers Window on Hurdles Ahead for Romney

abstract: Despite conservatives goal of reducing the burden on the poor with tax credits, Mitt Romney tapped into an anxiety that takers are overtaking makers.
author: ANNIE LOWREY and MICHAEL COOPER
headline: With Tax Comments, Romney Wades Into a Conservative Rift

abstract: Until now, Mitt Romneys campaign had been focused almost entirely on criticizing President Obama.
author: JIM RUTENBERG and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: On a Challenging Day, Romney Seeks to Shift to His Policy Specifics

abstract: With an outbreak of finger-pointing signaling trouble in his campaign, Mitt Romney plans to say more clearly what he wants for the country, his aides said.
author: JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY
headline: Amid Discord, Romney Seeks to Sharpen Message

abstract: Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice presidential candidate, uses an appearance to attack President Obama, while Mitt Romney and his wife chat it up with TV hosts.
author: ASHLEY PARKER and TRIP GABRIEL
headline: While Ryan Throws Hardballs, Romney Makes Friends on Morning TV

abstract: A presidential candidate who is not short of campaign promises is specific on some proposals, but vague on others.
author: MICHAEL COOPER
headline: Some Romney Proposals Await Fuller Detail

abstract: Mitt Romney, in an interview, used imprecise language on what his red line is on Irans nuclear program, saying it was acquisition of a weapon, not capability, as his aides have said.
author: DAVID E. SANGER and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Stumbles in Explaining Iran Policy

abstract: Senior foreign policy advisers for Mitt Romney provide a detailed narrative of how Romney would have handled a streak of recent crises in the Middle East, offering a specificity far greater than what Romney himself has offered on the campaign trail, where he speaks in board strokes about his foreign policy plans.
author: DAVID E. SANGER and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Amid Mideast Turmoil, Aides Say What a President Romney Would Do

abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column observes that private equitys use of carried interest to lower tax bills, though legal, has drawn criticism toward Mitt Romney; points out that another lesser-known method used by some firms, including Bain Capital, might not withstand an Internal Revenue Service challenge; notes it involves taxing management fees at lower capital gains rates.
author: FLOYD NORRIS
headline: A Tax Tactic Thats Open to Question

abstract: "Mitt Romney's position in favor of the Vietnam War during his freshman year in college reflected his family's views and his faith in traditional values, but his stance shifted markedly four years later when he called the war a mistake;" Romney's position while at Stanford University stood in stark contrast to the majority of the student population (Series: The Long Run).
author: MICHAEL WINES
headline: Dissecting Romneys Vietnam Stance at Stanford

abstract: Speaking to National Guard members in Reno, Nev., Mitt Romney expressed gratitude for troops serving overseas and said the defense budget should not be cut.
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: After Criticism of His Convention Speech, Romney Thanks Nations Armed Forces

abstract: Mitt Romney said that under his plan, those with existing conditions would be guaranteed access to health insurance, but that would apply only to patients who maintained continuous coverage.
author: ROBERT PEAR and ABBY GOODNOUGH
headline: It Will Be Tricky for Romney to Keep Best of Health Law While Repealing It

abstract: Mitt Romneys campaign rushed to quell anxiety among Republicans, saying any post-convention lift for President Obama would not last the next few weeks, let alone to Election Day.
author: JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY
headline: Romney Camp Seeks to Head Off Post-Convention Anxieties

abstract: Mitt Romney has pledged to cut individual income tax rates for everyone, but he has provided few specifics, confounding analysts and leaving himself open to attack from Democrats.
author: ANNIE LOWREY and DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI
headline: Romneys Tax Plan Leaves Key Variables Blank

abstract: In a rare interview on NBCs Meet the Press, Mitt Romney offered praise for some of President Obamas policies, and said he would retain some aspects of his health care overhaul.
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Romney, Easing, Says Health Law Isnt All Bad

abstract: At a rally Saturday, Mitt Romney did not just recite the Pledge of Allegiance; he metaphorically wrapped his stump speech in it, using each line of the pledge to attack President Obama.
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: In Romneys Hands, Pledge of Allegiance Is Framework for Criticism

abstract: Mitt Romney has turned his attention to preparing for the presidential debates, which he and his aides view as a decisive juncture in the campaign; preparation has included a series of mock debates at a secluded location in West Windsor, Vermont. Photo (M)t
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Romney Focus Is on Preparing For the Debates

abstract: Caucus column; Virgil Goode, the presidential nominee for the conservative Constitution Party, qualifies for Virginia's ballot, complicating Mitt Romney's chances of winning the swing state. Photo (M)
author: JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: Officially a Candidate

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney and the Republican National Convention raised about $100 million in August, the third nine-figure month in a row, putting him on pace to be one of the most successful Republican fund-raisers in history. (M)p
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
headline: Another Big Total for the G.O.P.

abstract: Check Point column finds that Democrats made a number of misleading claims about taxes, civil liberties and a Mitt Romney quote during their speeches at the Democratic National Convention; notes that Bill Clinton's impressive claim about the superiority of job creation under Democratic presidents appears to be true. (M)
author: MICHAEL COOPER, SCOTT SHANE and ANNIE LOWREY; Kitty Bennett contributed reporting
headline: A Startling Truth Amid the Hyperbole

abstract: Representative Paul D Ryan is the face of the Republican ticket once again, blitzing morning television shows and skipping between battleground states, fully embracing the role of tormentor in chief of President Obama; Mitt Romney keeps a low profile as he prepares for the coming presidential debates. (M)y
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Ryan Carries Load While Romney Readies for Debates

abstract: Virgil Goode, of the conservative Constitution Party, qualified Tuesday for Virginias ballot in November, complicating Mitt Romneys chances of winning the key swing state.
author: JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: Virgil Goode on Virginia Ballot Poses Worry for Romney

abstract: Mitt Romney tours hurricane-ravaged regions of the Louisiana bayou on the first day after formally accepting his party's nomination for president; visit, in which Romney met with Republican Gov Bobby Jindal, appears intended to convey an unmistakable air of presidential authority.
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Romney Shows Support in Storm-Battered Bayou

abstract: Mitt Romneys path to the White House would be severely narrowed without the 18 electoral votes from Ohio, where he continues to trail President Obama in polls.
author: JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY; Jim Rutenberg reported from Cincinnati, and Jeff Zeleny from Charlotte, N.C
headline: Romney Stakes Hopes on Ohio, A Tactical Test

abstract: Check Point column analyzes incorrect or incomplete facts in Mitt Romney and Paul D Ryan's acceptance speeches at the Republican National Convention; notes that these misrepresentations seem to signal the arrival of a campaign in which fact-checking concerns have been largely set aside.
author: MICHAEL COOPER
headline: Facts Take a Beating in Acceptance Speeches

abstract: New Jersey Gov Chris Christie has traveled to 15 states for Mitt Romney, raising money for him and speaking at political events; his story of how Romney became his man is a winner with crowds and offers a serviceable testimonial to nice-guy Mitt. Photos (M)d
author: MARK LEIBOVICH
headline: It's Not All About Him, He Said Often

abstract: Caucus column; Tim Pawlenty, former governor of Minnesota who was on Mitt Romney's shortlist of possible vice presidential running mates, is largely unnoticed as he attends the Republican National Convention. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: An Ex-Governor Slips By

abstract: Caucus column; Clint Eastwood, in one of the more unusual moments in Republican convention history, offers an eccentric, rambling and apparently unvetted endorsement of Mitt Romney at the Republican National Convention. Photo (M)m
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Surprise Speaker Delivers the Unexpected

abstract: Interviews with voters in Florida suggest that the Republican National Convention and Mitt Romney's acceptance speech were eclipsed by other concerns, including Hurricane Isaac's landfall, fatigue with both presidential campaigns, and the day-to-day realities of work and family life. Photos (M)d
author: SUSAN SAULNY
headline: Too Busy or Just Too Tired, Some Floridians Paid Convention Little Mind

abstract: Check Point column analyzes incorrect or incomplete facts in Mitt Romney and Paul D Ryan's acceptance speeches at the Republican National Convention; notes that these misrepresentations seem to signal the arrival of a campaign in which fact-checking concerns have been largely set aside. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL COOPER
headline: Facts Take a Beating In Acceptance Speeches

abstract: Republicans, even House challengers, are distancing themselves from the proposed Medicare cuts in Paul D. Ryans budget plan, even as he and Mitt Romney urge them to embrace it.
author: JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: Ryan's Budget Proposal Is Pitting G.O.P. Troops Against Top of the Ticket

abstract: Mitt Romney tours hurricane-ravaged regions of the Louisiana bayou on the first day after formally accepting his party's nomination for president; visit, in which Romney met with Republican Gov Bobby Jindal, appears intended to convey an unmistakable air of presidential authority. Photos (M)
author: JEREMY W. PETERS; Trip Gabriel contributed reporting from New Orleans, and Jackie Calmes from Fort Worth
headline: Romney Shows Support In Storm-Battered Bayou

abstract: Ann Romney wears the red silk taffeta Oscar de la Renta dress that her husband's advisers opposed during her much-anticipated speech at the Republican National Convention; reviews from the fashion news media about the look are largely positive.
author: BEE-SHYUAN CHANG
headline: Ann Romneys Red Dress Ended One Debate

abstract: Mitt Romney accepts the Republican presidential nomination by directly appealing to Americans who were captivated by Pres Obama's hopeful promises of change; pledges to deliver what Obama did not and move the country out of its economic downturn; speech, delivered on closing night of the Republican convention, signals an attempt to redefine the race around his business background. Photos, Charts (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY; Michael D. Shear, Adam Nagourney and Jonathan Weisman contributed reporting
headline: Romney Vows to Deliver Country From Economic Travails

abstract: Analysis of Ann Romney's speech to the Republican National Convention, where she sought to humanize her husband Mitt Romney and court American women with a confidential 'us-gals' approach. Photo, Chart (S)
headline: Deconstructing Ann Romney's Speech

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney's sister Jane Romney promises that a ban on abortion is 'never going to happen' under her brother's presidency, a reassurance to women that is at odds with the nominee's stance on the issue. (M)/
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Abortion Will Stay Legal, Romney's Sister Predicts

abstract: Ashley Parker and Michael Barbaro The Party column on wannabe hot spots on the grounds of the Republican National Convention, visit by an Italian exchange student who lived with Mitt Romney's family in 1959, and how delegates from states that went against the Republican party's wishes have been punished at the convention. Photos (M)a
author: ASHLEY PARKER and MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Where the Elite Meet (Open Bar, Anyone?)

abstract: Caucus column; unidentified Secret Service agent is pulled off Mitt Romney's campaign plane after leaving her loaded handgun in the bathroom; the agent is being questioned by supervisors, but the incident appears by all accounts to have been unintentional. (M)/
author: PETER BAKER
headline: On The Campaign Plane: Secret Service Gun Left Behind

abstract: Michael Barbaro and Ashley Parker The Party column; Mitt and Ann Romney, family members and much of the Romney campaign at the Republican National Convention are staying at the Tampa Marriott Waterside Hotel in Tampa, Fla; former New Hampshire Gov John Sununu is seen as the most unpredictable surrogate for Romney's campaign at the convention; single best and worst delegate seats at the convention floor are noted.
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: A Hotel Is Romney Central (Cart Coming Through!)

abstract: Alessandra Stanley The TV Watch column on Ann Romney, who gave a bold and boisterous tribute to her husband Mitt Romney at the Republican National Convention; says testimonial was also loving and generous and revealed just how much he owes his talented and determined spouse.
author: ALESSANDRA STANLEY
headline: Stepping Out of a Husbands Shadow, and Perhaps Overshadowing Him

abstract: Backers of Rep Ron Paul protest at the Republican National Convention what they say are moves by Republican leadership to squelch their movements rise; part of Maine's delegation walks out; protests signal deeper party divisions bubbling under the telegenic surface of Mitt Romney's nomination at the convention.
author: JIM RUTENBERG
headline: Paul Supporters Protest Signals Deeper Division

abstract: "Mitt Romney is formally nominated at the Republican National Convention to be the party's presidential candidate;" Romney's wife Ann leads the well-choreographed effort to reintroduce him to Americans in the hope of gaining the trust of voters and bolstering his campaign to defeat Pres Obama.
author: JEFF ZELENY
headline: Nomination Secure, Romney Pitch Starts

abstract: House Republicans, who less than two years ago led their party to power, are being granted little prominence at the Republican National Convention as Mitt Romney takes over, even though Rep Paul D Ryan has a starring role as vice presidential nominee; scarcity of his colleagues at convention may reflect unease within the party for an institution whose popularity is near rock bottom.
author: JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: House Republicans Deemed Not Ready for Convention’s Prime Time

abstract: Man in the News profile of Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, who for three years after his failed 2008 presidential campaign, sought to reclaim his public identity using tools he learned as the corporate consultant he once was; Romney may owe his nomination in no small measure to his self-critical eye, marketing savvy and systematic rigor. Photos (L)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO; Julie Bosman and Jo Craven McGinty contributed reporting from New York
headline: Defeat, Introspection, Reinvention, Nomination

abstract: Ann Romneys silk taffeta Oscar de la Renta dress for her speech Tuesday opened the debate on whether her clothing selection has any layered meaning.
author: BEE-SHYUAN CHANG; Peter Baker contributed reporting from Tampa and Stuart Emmrich from New York
headline: Ann Romney's Red Dress Ended One Debate

abstract: Republican National Convention is staging a carefully chosen tableau of speakers to discuss Mitt Romney's Mormon faith, a subject the candidate has largely resisted addressing in public for most of his political career, afraid it may affect his electability; Romney is expected to be portrayed as a man of compassion, character and deep beliefs. Photo (M)
author: JODI KANTOR; Reporting was contributed by Will Storey, Jonathan Weisman, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Jeff Zeleny and Jeremy W. Peters. Kitty Bennett contributed research
headline: Convention Voices Hope to Add Texture to Romney's Faith

abstract: Ashley Parker and Michael Barbaro The Party column; Mitt Romney's brother Scott reflects on his childhood and how the two learned about politics from their father George, the former governor of Michigan; gay rights advocates in the Republican Party say they are looking past the nominee's opposition to gay marriage and disagreements on other issues. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER and MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: An Older Brother, Now Playing Backup

abstract: Relationship between what presidential candidates say about foreign policy and what they do once elected can be tenuous; should Republican candidate Mitt Romney win in November, he may be no different in this respect than the men who preceded him, despite his tough talk on China, Iran and Russia; he may, however, put his own stamp on international affairs in ways both surprising and not. (M)
author: PETER BAKER
headline: Precise Foreign Policy Intentions Can Be Tough to Gauge

abstract: Alessandra Stanley The TV Watch column on Ann Romney, who gave a bold and boisterous tribute to her husband Mitt Romney at the Republican National Convention; says testimonial was also loving and generous and revealed just how much he owes his talented and determined spouse. Photo (M)
author: ALESSANDRA STANLEY
headline: Stepping Out of a Husband's Shadow, and Perhaps Overshadowing Him

abstract: Michael Barbaro and Ashley Parker The Party column; Mitt and Ann Romney, family members and much of the Romney campaign at the Republican National Convention are staying at the Tampa Marriott Waterside Hotel in Tampa, Fla; former New Hampshire Gov John Sununu is seen as the most unpredictable surrogate for Romney's campaign at the convention; single best and worst delegate seats at the convention floor are noted. Photos (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: A Hotel Is Romney Central (Cart Coming Through!)

abstract: Michael Barbaro and Ashley Parker The Party column; thousands of Republicans and reporters have time to kill in Tampa, Fla, after first day's events of Republican National Convention are canceled; Newt Gingrich unveils Newt University, series of lectures on conservative issues; Mormon Utah delegation takes on nervous excitement as Mitt Romney's campaign prepares to showcase his religion at the convention; New Jersey Gov Chris Christie displays typical bravado as he prepares to give keynote address.
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: On a Day Off for a Storm, Republicans Try to Keep Sharp

abstract: Mitt Romney is formally nominated at the Republican National Convention to be the party's presidential candidate; Romney's wife Ann leads the well-choreographed effort to reintroduce him to Americans in the hope of gaining the trust of voters and bolstering his campaign to defeat Pres Obama. Photos (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY; Jim Rutenberg and Michael D. Shear contributed reporting
headline: Romney Secures G.O.P Nomination After Long Quest

abstract: Backers of Rep Ron Paul protest at the Republican National Convention what they say are moves by Republican leadership to squelch their movement's rise; part of Maine's delegation walks out; protests signal deeper party divisions bubbling under the telegenic surface of Mitt Romney's nomination at the convention. Photo (M)i
author: JIM RUTENBERG
headline: Paul Supporters' Protest Signals Deeper Division

abstract: House Republicans, who less than two years ago led their party to power, are being granted little prominence at the Republican National Convention as Mitt Romney takes over, even though Rep Paul D Ryan has a starring role as vice presidential nominee; scarcity of his colleagues at convention may reflect unease within the party for an institution whose popularity is near rock bottom. (M)
author: JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: House Republicans Deemed Not Ready for Convention's Prime Time

abstract: Mitt Romneys pursuit of the Republican presidential nomination culminated Tuesday when the delegates gathered in Tampa officially made him their choice to reclaim the White House from the Democrats.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Jim Rutenberg and Michael Barbaro contributed reporting
headline: Delegates Anoint Romney as Nominee

abstract: Mitt Romney has embraced during his campaign the conservative view that government can best help the economy by getting smaller, but review of his positions on economic issues underscores the complexity of predicting how he might manage the national economy; his two decades in politics reveals a recurring tension between his political commitments and his private sector experience at Bain Capital, which he often cited earlier in his political career in advocating a larger government role in the economy. Photo (M)
author: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
headline: Romney Seen Pulled 2 Ways Over Economy

abstract: As governor of Massachusetts, Mitt Romney supported a greater government role in the economy, but as a presidential candidate, he has moved closer to the Republican mainstream.
author: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
headline: Romney Seen Pulled 2 Ways Over Economy

abstract: For a campaign struggling to humanize its candidate, the Romney clan provides a camera-ready tableau for a point his advisers want to underscore: Policies aside, Mitt Romney is a successful father.
author: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: With Five Romney Sons, Five More Spokesmen

abstract: Caucus column; group of Web videographers known as livestreamers are planning to broadcast live footage of protests at the Republican convention in Tampa, Fla; video evidence was key in clearing many of the protesters who were arrested at the 2004 convention in New York. (M)
author: COLIN MOYNIHAN
headline: Election 2012: Livestreaming the Show, From 'Romneyville'

abstract: Mitt Romney and top aides, worried that Tropical Storm Isaac could cause further disruption, head to Tampa, Fla, to quickly hold roll call vote to officially make him the Republican Party's presidential nominee; party leaders gavel convention to mark its formal opening and then quickly call a recess; frustration over delay brings fresh airing of intraparty tensions. Photo (M)
author: JIM RUTENBERG and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Jeff Zeleny, William Storey and Susan Saulny contributed reporting
headline: As Storm Disrupts Plans, G.O.P. Takes Up Tensions

abstract: Mitt Romneys speeches and rallies are highly polished and hyper-scripted and they tell a story of a man who sees himself as a hero prepared to pull off his biggest rescue yet.
author: ASHLEY PARKER and MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: Two Campaigns With Styles as Similar as Red and Blue

abstract: Michael Barbaro and Ashley Parker The Party column; thousands of Republicans and reporters have time to kill in Tampa, Fla, after first day's events of Republican National Convention are canceled; Newt Gingrich unveils Newt University, series of lectures on conservative issues; Mormon Utah delegation takes on nervous excitement as Mitt Romney's campaign prepares to showcase his religion at the convention; New Jersey Gov Chris Christie displays typical bravado as he prepares to give keynote address. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: On a Day Off for a Storm, Republicans Try to Keep Sharp

abstract: Prospect of a major storm blowing through the Gulf of Mexico toward New Orleans upsets the tight choreography of the Republican convention in Tampa, Fla; storm is straining the party's highly scripted plans for showcasing Mitt Romney, and raises the possibility that prized news media attention could shift elsewhere. Photos (M)8
author: JIM RUTENBERG and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Jeff Zeleny and Lizette Alvarez contributed reporting
headline: Storm Rewrites G.O.P. 's Script For Convention

abstract: Mitt Romney, attending the Republican National Convention, will accept the presidential nomination from a party that is increasingly divided by factionalism since the emergence of the Tea Party three years ago; some old-guard Republican leaders worry that their party's turn toward contentious social issues, and its increasingly antigovernment stance, may be pushing it out of the political mainstream. Photos (M)
author: ADAM NAGOURNEY
headline: A Party of Factions Gathers, Seeking Consensus

abstract: "Mitt Romney's advisers will seek to humanize him during the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla, making use of two key stories--his wife Ann's struggle with multiple sclerosis and his near-fatal car crash in 1968;" advisers believe the two stories will help construct a 'crisis narrative' in what has otherwise seemed a charmed existence for Romney (Series: The Long Run).
author: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG
headline: Romney in Crisis: Two Dark Spots in Fortunate Life

abstract: Mitt Romney's campaign extends an olive branch to the small army of Ron Paul delegates who will attend the Republican National Convention by scheduling a tribute video to Paul, even as it tries to make sure that such an insurgency does not arise in future campaigns.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: G.O.P. Convention Will Include Video Tribute to Paul

abstract: Unlike Sarah Palin, the Republican running mate in this election, Representative Paul D. Ryan, is staying in the background and giving ground on policy.
author: TRIP GABRIEL and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan Present a United Front

abstract: Political Memo; Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's selection of Rep Paul D Ryan as his running mate undercuts his longstanding campaign theme of being a Washington outsider. (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Political Memo: By Adding Ryan as Running Mate, Romney Loses Outsider Status

abstract: Mitt Romney is heading into the Republican National Convention with his advisers convinced he needs a more combative footing against Pres Obama in order to appeal to white, working-class voters; Romney's campaign remains focused on the economy as the issue that can defeat Obama, but Romny has added a harder edge to his economic message, injecting volatile cultural themes into the race. Photo, Map, Chart, Graphs (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG
headline: Romney Adopts Harder Message For Last Stretch

abstract: Caucus column; Denver television reporter Shaun Boyd says Mitt Romney's campaign demanded she not ask him in a brief interview about abortion or Rep Todd Akin. (M)/
author: BRIAN STELTER
headline: Abortion and Akin Off-Limits

abstract: Plans are underway for Mitt Romney to be nominated for president at the Republican National Convention on Monday, Aug 27, not Wednesday, Aug 29, as previously scheduled; reasons for shift are twofold--potential threat from Tropical Storm Isaac and concerns about a possible disruption during the roll call vote from Ron Paul supporters. (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY
headline: A Threatened Storm May Speed Up Romney's Nomination

abstract: James B Stewart Common Sense column cites experts who are looking at the tax code involving foreign tax credits, and pointing to intriguing clues buried in the returns Mitt Romney has released; notes his 2010 return has 10 years' worth of data on foreign taxes he paid, and shows how wealthy Americans with foreign earnings can sharply reduce their tax liability in the United States. Photo (M)
author: JAMES B. STEWART
headline: Tax Credits Shed Light On Romney

abstract: Mitt Romney's campaign extends an olive branch to the small army of Ron Paul delegates who will attend the Republican National Convention by scheduling a tribute video to Paul, even as it tries to make sure that such an insurgency does not arise in future campaigns. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: G.O.P. Convention Will Include Video Tribute to Paul

abstract: Presumed Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney seems to make a joke about Pres Obama's birth certificate while speaking to voters in his home state of Michigan, reinjecting the issue of Obama's birthplace into the campaign. Photo (M)y
author: ASHLEY PARKER and TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Romney, in His Home State, Raises Birth Certificate Issue

abstract: Mitt Romneys campaign advisers conclude they do not need any major adjustments in strategy to respond to new focus on abortion and reproductive rights caused by Rep Todd Akin; they are betting Romney's economic message will still resonate with female voters after the controversy over Akins remarks about 'legitimate rape' subsides.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: Romney Strategists Say Theyll Stay the Course Amid Focus on Abortion

abstract: Mitt Romney's campaign advisers conclude they do not need any major adjustments in strategy to respond to new focus on abortion and reproductive rights caused by Rep Todd Akin; they are betting Romney's economic message will still resonate with female voters after the controversy over Akin's remarks about 'legitimate rape' subsides. Chart (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: Romney Strategists Say They'll Stay the Course Amid Focus on Abortion

abstract: Confidential internal documents from the private equity firm Bain Capital, published online, highlight the range and complexity of investments held by Mitt Romney's family trusts; on display also are the aggressive strategies that Bain appears to have used to minimize its investors' and partners' tax liabilities. (M)
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE, FLOYD NORRIS and JULIE CRESWELL
headline: Documents Show Details on Romney Family Trusts

abstract: Caucus column; Romney campaign embraces Chris McMurray, Roanoke, Va, bakery owner who declined Vice Pres Joseph R Biden Jr's request to visit his shop. (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Baker Who Rebuffed Biden Gives Ryan Warm Welcome

abstract: He used an oversize bar graph to help unveil his new energy plan, but despite its large size the graph was all but impossible for those in the audience to read.
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Romney Uses Array of Props to Explain Ideas to Voters

abstract: Sen Scott P Brown of Massachusetts, who is locked in a dead heat in the nations most expensive Senate race, is distancing himself from the Republican ticket; with the possibility of a Romney-Ryan administration, he is reaffirming his independence; Brown has successfully navigated the treacherous waters for Republicans in the state in part by avoiding national issues.
author: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
headline: Former G.O.P. Hero Plays Down Label

abstract: Spokesman for the New York archdiocese says that Cardinal Timothy M Dolan will deliver the closing prayer at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla, after Mitt Romney accepts the party's presidential nomination. (M)/
author: SHARON OTTERMAN; Laurie Goodstein contributed reporting
headline: Dolan to Give Benediction At Gathering Of the G.O.P.

abstract: Mitt Romney plans to unveil an energy plan that allows states more control over the development of energy resources on federal lands within their borders; proposal, which is likely to be controversial among environmentalists, would also aggressively expand offshore oil and gas drilling as part of a broader effort to reach energy independence. Photos (M)
author: CLIFFORD KRAUSS and ASHLEY PARKER; Clifford Krauss reported from Houston, and Ashley Parker from Bettendorf, Iowa
headline: Romney Energy Plan Would Expand Oil Drilling on U.S. Land and Offshore

abstract: Caucus column; Ron Paul's presidential campaign reaches agreement with Republican leaders on delegate disputes, clearing the way for a harmonious national convention to nominate Mitt Romney; deal will seat at least 22 delegates. (M)t
author: JOHN HARWOOD
headline: Paul and Party Officials Reach Deal on Delegates

abstract: Presumed Republican presidential contender Mitt Romney criticizes the Obama administration for spending $90 billion on green energy, yet some of the money was appropriated during the Bush administration and went to programs signed into law by Pres George W Bush. Photo (M)
author: MATTHEW WALD
headline: A Romney Attack Line Found Not So Clear-Cut

abstract: Television networks are scaling back coverage of 2012's political conventions, believing that Americans are disinterested in a lackluster campaign season; say they will broadcast one hour of the Republican convention on its final three nights, but no more, angering Romney advisers who face a blackout of the opening-night program they fastidiously scripted to soften perceptions of the candidate. Photos (M)
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Limited Convention Broadcasts Shut Out Ann Romney

abstract: Campaign advisers say Mr. Romneys economic message will still resonate with female voters after the controversy created by Todd Akins legitimate rape comment subsides.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JONATHAN WEISMAN
headline: Romney Strategists Say They'll Stay the Course Amid Focus on Abortion

abstract: Caucus column; eight of the 10 National Basketball Association owners who have made contributions to the presidential candidates' campaigns so far have donated to Mitt Romney's campaign, for a total of $49,000. (M)1
author: NICK CORASANITI;
headline: Team Play: For N.B.A. Team Owners, Romney Is Their First Pick

abstract: Republican Party's agenda on restricting abortion rights has wedged its way to the center of the 2012 campaign because of Rep Todd Akin's remarks on rape; Akin's record on abortion is largely indistinguishable from his House Republican colleagues, and issue may prove politically volatile for Mitt Romney and other candidates, who would prefer to focus on economic issues. Photo (M)
author: JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Pam Belluck and Michael Cooper contributed reporting from New York
headline: Ignoring Deadline to Quit, G.O.P. Senate Candidate Defies His Party Leaders: Unexpected Twist in the Election Campaigns

abstract: Sen Scott P Brown of Massachusetts, who is locked in a dead heat in the nation's most expensive Senate race, is distancing himself from the Republican ticket; with the possibility of a Romney-Ryan administration, he is reaffirming his independence; Brown has successfully navigated the treacherous waters for Republicans in the state in part by avoiding national issues. Photos (M)
author: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
headline: Former G.O.P. Hero Plays Down Label

abstract: Some health care experts say the $716 billion that Mitt Romney has promised to restore to hospitals and insurers would hasten Medicare's insolvency by eight years, to 2016 from 2024; say restoring reimbursement cuts would add hundreds of dollars a year to out-of-pocket expenses for beneficiaries. Photos, Chart (M)1
author: JACKIE CALMES
headline: Patients Would Pay More if Romney Restores Medicare Savings, Analysts Say

abstract: FiveThirtyEight blog; Mitt Romney's selection of Paul Ryan as his running mate seems be specifically because of his conservative policy views and the way he articulates them, representing a big bet by the Romney campaign that Republicans can win elections without having to compromise. Photos (M)
author: NATE SILVER
headline: In Picking Ryan, Romney Makes an All-In Move

abstract: Mitt Romneys campaign has recruited professionals to manage his appearance at the Republican convention, hoping to overcome his image of being stiff and aloof.
author: JEREMY W. PETERS;
headline: G.O.P. Packaging Seeks to Reveal A Warm Romney

abstract: Mitt Romney and his vice-presidential candidate Rep Paul D Ryan campaign in New Hampshire; Democrats highlight Ryan's record of opposing abortion. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and TRIP GABRIEL; Mark Landler contributed reporting from Washington
headline: As Romney Enjoys Ryan's Spark, Rivals Try to Fan It

abstract: Mitt Romney's campaign has recruited professionals to manage his appearance at the Republican National Convention, hoping to overcome his image of being stiff and aloof; Romney, who has experience coordinating large-scale events, has had a direct hand in shaping some major aspects of the convention, from the open and approachable podium design to the theme. Photos (M)
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: G.O.P. Packaging Seeks to Reveal A Warm Romney

abstract: Mitt Romney's aides invite reporters, for the first time, to accompany him to church services, offering a rare glimpse into the private life of a candidate who almost never talks about his Mormon faith. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO and ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Scripture, Song and Six Grandchildren: Romneys Open Church Doors to Press

abstract: Mitt Romney has to raise money, work on his acceptance speech, prepare for debates and rally supporters  without making any mistakes.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Romneys To-Do List Before the Republican Convention

abstract: A congenial meeting in 2007 led to closer collaboration, especially in the last 18 months, as the Republican Party shifted more to the right.
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: The Courtship Before Romney Elevated Ryan

abstract: Caucus column; Mitt Romney's running mate Rep Paul D Ryan says it was a mistake for him to have requested funds in 2009 from the federal stimulus bill after voting against it. (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Setting The Record Straight: Ryan Says He Erred In Seeking Stimulus Money

abstract: Mitt Romney says he paid at least 13 percent of his income in taxes each year during the past decade, again confronting a vexing issue that Democrats have used to portray him as out of touch with middle-class values; Romney's comments appeared to be an off-the-cuff attempt to put the issue behind him once and for all but they seem to have had the opposite effect, with Democrats seizing on them to revive the issue and demand proof of his claims. (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Jeff Zeleny contributed reporting
headline: Romney Says He Paid At Least 13% In Income Taxes

abstract: Mitt Romney's transition team is busy putting together a framework should he win the White House, offering a glimpse into what his approach to governing might be. Photo (M)
author: ASHLEY PARKER
headline: Campaigning Aside, Team Plans a Romney Presidency

abstract: Republican vice-presidential candidate Rep Paul Ryan is a fan of DVD workout regime P90X, created by physical trainer Tony Horton and produced and distributed by Beachbody LLC; Ryan, who was a physical trainer briefly after college, has been organizing P90X workouts with a group of other congressman, and even Mitt Romney has said he is will to give it a try. Photo (M)
author: AUSTIN CONSIDINE
headline: A Beach Body Built in Wisconsin

abstract: Caucus column; Vice Pres Joseph R Biden Jr creates a stir at a campaign stop in Virginia when he tells the crowd that presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's policies will enable the banking and financial sectors to 'put you all back in chains.' (M)/
author: REBECCA BERG
headline: On The Trail: A Metaphor Draws Notice

abstract: Michael Powell Gotham column notes that Mitt Romney has publicly tapped Gov Chris Christie of New Jersey as the keynote speaker at the Republican National Convention; holds that Christie's promise to deliver 'very direct and hard truths' to the American people should start before he builds any myth-based narrative for the convention--with some truths about the dire economic condition of his own state. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL POWELL
headline: Little Candor From Christie Before Keynote

abstract: "Representative Paul D Ryan began developing self-reliance and a political philosophy as a teen after his father died that has culminated into a defining role as a vice-presidential candidate;" in Ryan, Mitt Romney has found not only a sympathetic life story to animate his campaign but also a politician who fills in what many see as the gaps in Romneys conservative bona fides (Series: The Long Run).
author: JENNIFER STEINHAUER, JIM RUTENBERG, MIKE McINTIRE and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG
headline: Conservative Stars Small-Town Roots

abstract: Reporter's Notebook; Mitt Romney and his newly announced vice-presidential running mate, Rep Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin, appear to have an easy and instant chemistry on the campaign trail. (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: An Easy and Instant Chemistry on the Trail

abstract: Mitt Romney's choice of Tea Party favorite Rep Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate moves what was once considered a conservative fringe movement toward the political center and helps validate Romney in the eyes of skeptical Tea Party members in the House. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: Tea Party Hopes to Gain Larger Stage in Election With Romney's Pick

abstract: Mitt Romney appears to have chosen Rep Paul D Ryan as his vice-presidential running mate not only for his knowledge of the federal budget, but also because he has close ties to the network of major conservative and libertarian donors and activists with deep pockets. Photo (M)1
author: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE; Griff Palmer contributed reporting
headline: Ryan Has Kept Close Ties to Donors on the Right

abstract: Medicare comes to the forefront as an election issue with presumptive Republican nominee Mitt Romney's selection of Rep Paul D Ryan as his running mate; Florida emerges as a test of the Republican Party's gamble that concerns over the deficit will trump voters' worries about Ryan's proposed Medicare overhaul. Photos, Graphs (M)d
author: ADAM NAGOURNEY; Reporting was contributed by Michael Barbaro in St. Augustine, Fla.; Carlos Harrison in Miami; Fernanda Santos in Sun City, Ariz.; and Susan Saulny in Scranton, Pa
headline: Medicare Rises As Voters' Issue In G.O.P. Gamble

abstract: "Mitt Romney introduces Rep Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate at a spirited rally in Norfolk, Va, bringing to his side one of the partys young conservative leaders in a move that alters the contours of the campaign and sharpens the choice facing the voters in November;" selection of Ryan, the chief architect of the Republican plan for tax and spending cuts and an advocate of reshaping the Medicare program, is an effort to reset the race with President Obama. ("See also" Presidential Election of 2012)
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG
headline: Romney Chooses Ryan, Pushing Fiscal Issues to the Forefront

abstract: Rep Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin, who has been chosen as Mitt Romney's vice-presidential running mate, has said he wants to focus on the nation's looming debt crisis, but Democrats are assailing his stances on issues like abortion, gun control and women's health. (M)
author: ROBERT PEAR
headline: As Ryan Looks to Focus On Economy, Spotlight Shines on His Other Views

abstract: Mitt Romney's campaign took extraordinary measures to keep his selection of Paul Ryan as running mate a secret until he chose to unveil it; chart compares Ryan's career experience with that of recent vice presidents. Photo, Chart (M)1
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: How Campaign Outwitted The 24-Hour News Cycle

abstract: Democrats move aggressively to wrap Mitt Romney in the politically charged details of budget-cutting proposals championed by his new running mate, Rep Paul D Ryan, as Romney seeks to capitalize on conservative enthusiasm for his choice without having to defend every element of Ryan's positions; Ryan's introduction to a national audience is defined by his plan to reshape Medicare and slash spending for nearly all government programs. Photo (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and MICHAEL BARBARO; Jodi Kantor contributed reporting from Chicago
headline: Both Sides Focus On The New Face

abstract: Rep Paul D Ryan, Mitt Romney's choice for vice-presidential running mate, is idolized by young conservatives in the House, who see him as a role model and a polished spokesman for their vision of America. Photos (M)s
author: ROBERT PEAR
headline: Running Mate Is an Upbeat Budget Cutter, Eager to Joust With Democrats

abstract: News analysis explores Mitt Romney's gamble in tapping as his running mate Rep Paul D Ryan, the author of the audacious House Republican budget plan; says decision could quiet criticism over his lack of detail behind his promise to reduce the nation's rising debt through sweeping spending cuts and tax changes; Ryan plan, which Romney endorsed during the hard-fought race for the Republican presidential nomination, would cut about $6 trillion from projected spending in the first 10 years. Graph, Photo (M)
author: JACKIE CALMES
headline: Elevating the Man, and His Budget Details

abstract: Mitt Romney introduces Rep Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin as his running mate at a spirited rally in Norfolk, Va, bringing to his side one of the party's young conservative leaders in a move that alters the contours of the campaign and sharpens the choice facing the voters in November; selection of Ryan, the chief architect of the Republican plan for tax and spending cuts and an advocate of reshaping the Medicare program, is an effort to reset the race with President Obama. ( See also Presidential Election of 2012) Photos (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from Norfolk, Va
headline: Romney Chooses Ryan, Pushing Fiscal Issues to the Forefrunt

abstract: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan's differences in background and style seem more pronounced than their similarities, but aides to Romney say that those distinctions are precisely what they consider part of Ryan's appeal. Photo (M)
author: MICHAEL BARBARO
headline: A Team That Seems Comfortable With the Contrasts

abstract: Mitt Romney is scheduled to announce his vice presidential candidate on August 11, in Norfolk, Va, with several signs pointing toward Representative Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin as the leading candidate for the position; announcement will end a four-month search for a running mate on the opening day of a four-day bus tour through four critical battleground states. Photo (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY and MICHAEL BARBARO; Jeff Zeleny reported from Washington, and Michael Barbaro from Norfolk, Va. Michael D. Shear contributed reporting from Norfolk
headline: Romney Is Ready To Name Choice Of Running Mate

abstract: "Nearly lost among the blizzard of hedge funds, thoroughbred horses and other gold-plated investments in Mitt Romneys portfolio is less than $2,500 in annual interest income from a mortgage on Timothy and Betty Stampss Texas home;" to Romney the $600 monthly checks are loose change but for the Stampses the money they borrowed from him to buy their home in 1997 was life-changing; mortgage is the last vestige of a troubled investment Romney made in Texas real estate before he struck it rich as the wunderkind of Bain Capital.
author: MIKE McINTIRE
headline: In Real Estate Deal, Romney Made His Loss a Couples Gain

abstract: Conservatives are pushing Mitt Romney to erase doubts about his agenda by choosing Rep Paul D Ryan as his running mate; Ryan, a champion of cutting government spending and reining in the costs of entitlement programs, would do much to reassure the conservative base that Romney stands behind their fiscal agenda.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and TRIP GABRIEL
headline: Romney Faces Pressure From Right to Put Ryan on Ticket

abstract: Caucus column; analysts note that Wikipedia entries for vice presidential candidates often undergo rapid editing in the days before they are picked, metric that seems to indicate Rep Paul D Ryan as a strong possible choice for Mitt Romney. Photo (M)1
author: NOAM COHEN
headline: The Running Mate: Reading the Tea Leaves In the Pages of Wikipedia

abstract: Mitt Romney's campaign is working to narrow a perceived empathy gap between Romney and Pres Obama, who is seen by voters as more likable and easier to relate to. Photo (M)
author: JEFF ZELENY
headline: New Focus for Romney on Connecting and Closing the Empathy Gap

abstract: James B Stewart Common Sense column discusses data provided by the Internal Revenue Service from the 400 individual tax returns reporting the highest adjusted gross income; says they demonstrate how many of the ultrarich reduce their tax liability, and provides some insight into what might be in Mitt Romney's returns. (M)
author: JAMES B. STEWART
headline: In the Superrich, Clues to What Might Be in Romney's Tax Returns

abstract: Guests and family an Orthodox Jewish wedding in Lakewood, NJ, momentarily abandon the couple to chase Mitt Romney's motorcade, which was driving past on its way to a nearby campaign fund-raising stop; while Romney seemed to have committed the worst type of social sin, upstaging a bride at her wedding, he ultimately posed with the bride and groom, who told him they are supporters. Photo (M)
author: SARAH WHEATON
headline: At a New Jersey Wedding, a Surprise Stop by Romney

abstract: Nearly lost among the blizzard of hedge funds, thoroughbred horses and other gold-plated investments in Mitt Romney's portfolio is less than $2,500 in annual interest income from a mortgage on Timothy and Betty Stamps's Texas home; to Romney the $600 monthly checks are loose change but for the Stampses the money they borrowed from him to buy their home in 1997 was life-changing; mortgage is the last vestige of a troubled investment Romney made in Texas real estate before he struck it rich as the wunderkind of Bain Capital. Photo (M)
author: MIKE McINTIRE
headline: On Romney's Ledger, a Couple's Happy Ending

abstract: Conservatives are pushing Mitt Romney to erase doubts about his agenda by choosing Rep Paul D Ryan as his running mate; Ryan, a champion of cutting government spending and reining in the costs of entitlement programs, would do much to reassure the conservative base that Romney stands behind their fiscal agenda. Photos (M)1
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and TRIP GABRIEL; Michael D. Shear reported from Washington, and Trip Gabriel from New York
headline: A Conservative Bid for Ryan to Be Romney's Running Mate

abstract: Mitt Romney's approach to choosing speakers for the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Florida, has prized efficiency and practicality over sentimentality; his choices have the potential to turn off the independent voters that the carefully choreographed convention is meant to sway. Photos (M)a
author: JEREMY W. PETERS
headline: Many Clamor for Convention Roles, but More Are Out Than In

abstract: Mitt Romney spends a day with no public events running errands and meeting with advisers at his vacation home in Wolfeboro, NH, as many speculate on his vice-presidential choice. Photo (M)
author: TRIP GABRIEL
headline: On a Day Off the Trail, Errands and Small Talk

abstract: Caucus column speculates on when Mitt Romney might announce his vice-presidential pick. (M)0
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
headline: A Big Decision, With Its Timing Carefully Planned

abstract: Top Republicans condemn Sen Harry Reid, accusing the Senate majority leader of fabricating an assertion that Mitt Romney did not pay taxes over a 10-year period. (M)
author: EMMARIE HUETTEMAN
headline: Republicans Attack Senate Leader After Assertion That Romney Did Not Pay Taxes

abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney campaigns in Indiana for Richard Mourdock, a Senate nominee and Tea Party favorite; Romney does not discuss bipartisanship, which he often speaks favorably about, but underscores his commitment to some Tea Party principles.
author: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
headline: Making a Pitch to the Tea Party in Indiana

abstract: Senate majority leader Harry Reid, who has long been publicly contemptuous of Mitt Romney, has drawn angry retorts from Republicans and Romney with his claims that Romney has not paid taxes in a decade.
author: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
headline: In Reids Taunting of Romney, Taxes Are Just a New Opening
